Is this game a spiritual successor to Chaos in the Old World or Midgard? It has a different feel from both. In CitOW, your race determines your strategy, whereas in BR you have to adapt a bit, depending on what cards come your way. Also, there are no dice. I also like the bluff element with the Loki cards. The minis are highly detailed and the monsters are crazy good. Happy that some of the KS exclusives actually add to the game and are not useless. As for Midgard, well, it was more of a straight-forward area control game with card drafting. It's a fun game, but it certainly lacks the theme that Blood Rage has. I see no reason to own Midgard, but I can see owning BR and CitOW.

Sweet miniatures and theming. The gameplay is easy to grasp and teach and the game itself is probably the perfect length. They really tightened up the design for this area control card drafter...even compared to Chaos in the Old World. (Which I might like a tad more.)

The miniatures in this game are amazing and really help bring the theme to life. Despite an epic instruction book the game is actually very simple. Though I was probably halfway through the second age on a first play before I had any real strategy. If I had one criticism it's that the first round is a little hampered by the low rage setting, which would be ok if the game wasn't only 3 rounds long. It's a fantastic game with some tough decisions though, particularly in the drafting where you know you might be taking a good card, but handing a card to your opponent that cancels it out.

My tip; monsters look cool, but they are costly to keep putting out.

This was the game that made me like an area control experience. The reason being, obviously, that is not really about area control. While a solid presence on the board can be visually satisfying and point rewarding via quests and battles, the variety of other scoring opportunities (special combat cards, Loki-losing-battles-for-stuff abilities, ragnarok positional strategy and the like) combined with the inherent challenges of drafting makes for a tense, relevant gameplay experience that is unbelievably quick paced (in that every turn takes a moment and every battle is potentially open to every player).

From a legit name and design to a great style of play that's what Blood Rage is. Blood Rage comes in with wonderful designed minis which arise from the viking mythology. Starting with a card drafting system, then you place your brave warriors trying to gain the most glory during three rounds. There are many ways to gather points by sacraficing your own folk to Ragnarök or by simply conquer your enemies. The mechanism is super easy but give a lot of place for strategy and tactical maneuvers. The theme is also caught fully by this masterpiece.

Was a lot better when played with correct rules. On the other hand, combat has some of the "I don't even get to play" problem common to blind-bid games; I probably favor using Loki cards to profit from losing battles a little too much just because otherwise I hate losing.

Taken me a while to sit down and rate this, and I'm kind of hesitant about where it's at. The game feels good, I'm a huge fan of how well everything comes together: A very seamless integration of a relatively unique set of mechanics (Drafting, Area Control, Tableau-esque). But, it doesn't feel great, and I have some ideas as to why.

[b]Pacing:[/b] The game says 60-90 minutes, I don't know if I've ever hit that. I see how it could get there with more practice such that drafting and card abilities become more familiar but it took nearly four hours when I took it out for the 4th play (After a long break between plays).
[b]Identity Crisis[/b] Now I don't generally think this is a bad thing, and it's nice to have a wide variety of viable strategies. But the game tends to have very little going on strategically, in that your initial strategic choice tends to be meaningless. Your choices end up being very reactive (tactical) based on drafting, and change drastically age-age with little carry over except for a very small set of Clan upgrades. I think that this degree of disjointedness bothers me because it flip flops strategy and tactics more frequently than I would like.

7 Wonders meets Chaos in the Old World in Kemet.  I wouldn't describe myself as an Eric Lang fanboy but I will never pass up an opportunity to try one of his designs.  Drafting is a great balancing mechanic and the card 'families' in Blood Rage offer players the chance to create some strategic lines to guide play.  Board play may seems chaotic to the uninitiated and... stay awake, or some denizen from Hell will appear in your province and obliterate your clan, and your chances of victory.  Yet you do have fragments of information about what dangers might lurk in the clammy hands of your opponents and what they might be up to- enabling you to foil their evil plans-mwah,ha,ha,ha.  Player interactivity is on the medium-high side so you are rarely unengaged.  It also scales really well.  I would choose Kemet over Blood Rage with 5 players.  However, Blood Rage will hit the table more often because the 3 and 4 player game is just as satisfying as the full bhuna.  Oh, it looks great too.

This game has a lot going for it.  Cool miniatures, lots of fighting and conflict and a lot of different ways to go about winning.  It's rare to see a run away leader but sometimes you do get a player left behind a little bit, although mostly you do have a chance to make up a lot of territory in the 3rd age of the game.  From the same makers as Chaos in the old World, and you can see the similarities in the way figures are placed on the board and actions are limited.  Personally I think Chaos in the Old World is superior, but I think Blood Rage is a bit simply and has more mass appeal.

A really fun game with a great theme and some amazing figures.  The difficulty and tension ramps up nicely throughout the game and it's possible for players to make late come-backs and win from a long way behind.

The main drawback is the drafting system.  This gives a big advantage to experienced players of the game, who will know good combinations of cards and what to look out for.  Also the cards are unbalanced, with some being much more powerful than others, and each of the 3 ages in the game can be made much easier if you get the right cards.  The last age in particular has one card that helps gain a huge amount of victory points for very little effort and the winner of the last 4 games I've played used this card.

With a bit better balancing of the cards this would be an even higher rated game.

Blood Rage is an area control game with an excellent action allocation mechanic. The drafting, I'm neither here nor there. It does the job well enough to set up your engine, but it leads to necessary "hate drafting" in later rounds. I prefer Kemet's style of engine building where everything is a positive interaction. What I love about Blood Rage, through, is the power activation. Each turn players can be active as long as they wish, as long as they are managing their power. With only three rounds, this creates a nice tension that is both self controlled and heavily pushed by opponents. It is more difficult to teach than Lang's Chaos in the Old World, but also a little smoother to play. Blood Rage does a good job with its interactions. It keeps players feeling able to compete even after they suffered from an unsuccessful sweeping move. There is a lot to like here. A few to many "check-up" phases in-between turns and I don't think drafting adds much to the game but an engaging game nonetheless.

This game you could call sort of the spiritual successor to Chaos in the Old World. There are definitely similarities between the two games and it becomes very obvious soon, that it comes from the same designer. Just that Blood Rage has much more impressive miniatures and the gameplay seems a bit more fluent and especially balanced.

Why not a 10?
Blood Rage is, apart from the miniatures, missing really deep and wonderful design. The board looks a little bit boring compared with Chaos in the Old World. Also the cards and side boards (Valhalla, Clan Boards) are not that beautifully designed. Still they are good, but missing the little extra.
From a gaming point of view Blood Rage has only little issues.
For example two clans, of course hating each other like hell, are standing there with some units in one and the same country, they cannot fight against each other, if that country has already been pillaged in this age. This is really sort of strange to me. I mean this is like two clans running towards each other, roaring out their Viking Rage and then just stop saying “Oh… The country has already been pillaged… No, no… Then I’m not gonna cut your head off. Let’s start a fire and have a BBQ.”. This just feels wrong.

Player Count:
It goes very well with 3 or 4 players. I haven’t played it with 2, but have to admit, that I don’t think that would be really interesting and would also face some additional issues.

Recommendation:
Yes, it is better than Chaos in the Old World! Even if you got Chaos at home, give this one a shot, it’s worth it.

Who should not buy it:
People who don’t like Viking mythology, Fans of colorful and happy games

Got to play this on the BGG@sea cruise 2017. was impressed at how fluid the game was. I have been disappointed in a few other CMON games so came in with low expectations and was greeted with a light rules but great depth game. you can go with what your cards give or try to hold to a strategy and both can pay out in the end. An interesting evolution of "Midgard", keeping the card draft and some of the area majority scoring, but much more focused on combat. I sometimes wish "Blood Rage" was more similar to its predecessor, just with far superior components and artwork, but this is just because I'm more of a Euro gamer. It is more like a Euro-Ameritrash hybrid, but it does well what it intends to do and may please fans of both genres.

The draft that starts each of the three rounds is full of agonizing decisions, as most cards feel overpowered (in a good way) and you don't want to give them to your opponents. Then you play upgrades and deploy troops or monsters that will eventually have to fight to pillage regions. The diceless combat is quick and simple, which is a good thing.

Interestingly, I found a bit of similarity to "Cthulhu Wars" in the way that you spend rage to perform actions and how your clan gains different skills as the game progresses. But "Blood Rage" doesn't have big swings of power and doesn't rely on ganging up on the leader to keep the game balanced. In fact, the dynamics of the game make it very hard to gang up on any one player.

The only real flaw is that the central region, Yggdrasil, may be too important. It increases all your three stats if you successfully pillage it, while other regions increase only one. And since troops that lose a battle are destroyed, it's not uncommon for a player to hold it for the entire game (and most often win).

The miniatures are fantastic, even though I would have preferred the vikings to be in the player colors, instead of identified only by a colored band put around the base. This should have been a solution just for the monsters. Nonetheless, the miniatures really enrich the experience and I probably would rate the game lower if it didn't have them.

It's a lot of fun, and it's fluid and fast-moving. I have concerns about the cards, though. In principle, yes, drafting should take care of concerns about card balance--but I'm not sure there's much room for hate-drafting in this game. In a game like Fairy Tale, where you will only play 60% of your cards, you could easily hate-draft. But in Blood Rage, you can easily play all of your cards each era, which encourages everyone just maximizing your own strategy's score. If that's true, then I worry that some strategies are vastly superior to others--compare the points for dead dudes vs. ship upgrades, for example.
But it's still very fun and it seems to win friends wherever it goes.
[EDIT] Further evidence seems to be allaying my fears. This sucker appears to have legs.

This game fell in my estimation after a few plays. Its strategies, while seemingly complex and divergent at first blush, are obvious, its minis underutilized, its board relatively uninteresting, and it has a tendency to feature a runaway leader. In this case, that leader was me. I don't speak from the perspective of sour grapes.

While it is, moment to moment, good fun and theoretically expansive enough, it's ultimately an area control game that has its priorities misaligned and waylaid by cardplay. Those first ten minutes of drafting basically supercede the entire area control aspect. Kemet and Siege of Columbia did a better job of balancing power/engine acquisition and "dudes on a map."

I used to hate drafting. I've since made peace with it and accept it as seasoning (ex: Steampunk Rally), but not as the main course. I'll play this, but there are better options.

1 neu aufgerüstete Spielfigur darf sofort ohne weitere Wut-Kosten Invadieren (außer mystiker!)

AUFWERTUNGEN

Friggs Beistand (I) und Dunkelelf (II)

Frage: Wenn ich die Clan-Aufrüstung Friggs Beistand im Spiel habe und mit dem Dunkelelf Yggdrasil invadiere, darf ich dann auch dorthin mit 1 Krieger zusätzlich ohne Kosten invadieren? Denn Krieger können Yggdrasil ja nicht invadieren. Außerdem: Kostet es 1 Wut mit dem Dunkelelf Yggdrasil zu invadieren oder 3 Wut, da seine Stärke dort ja 3 beträgt.
Antwort: Der Dunkelelf kostet immer nur 1 Wut, wenn er invadiert, auch nach Yggdrasil. Friggs Beistand erlaubt es auch, 1 Krieger mit nach Yggdrasil zu nehmen, wenn der Dunkelelf dorthin invadiert.

Friggs Beistand (I) und Schiffe

Frage: Wenn ich die Clan-Aufrüstung Friggs Beistand im Spiel habe und mit einem Schiff invadiere, darf ich auch dann mit 1 Krieger zusätzlich ohne Kosten invadieren? Wenn ja, wohin?
Antwort: Ja, diese Aufrüstung gilt für jedwede Invasion, auch für Schiffe. In diesem Fall darf der zusätzliche Krieger in eines der beiden Gebiete gestellt werden, die angrenzend zu dem Fjord sind, den das Schiff invadiert hat.

  Friggs Schutz (II)

Frage: Friggs Schutz sagt: „Du darfst 1 Wut bezahlen, um zu verhindern, das 1 deiner Spielfiguren getötet wird.“ Darf man das mehrfach machen, vorausgesetzt man kann die Wut bezahlen?
Antwort: Ja, man kann beliebig viele eigene Spielfiguren retten, solange man für jede gerettete Spielfigur 1 Wut bezahlt.

Völva (III)

Frage: Die Völva kann sich nach Yggdrasil zurückziehen, anstatt getötet zu werden. Was passiert, wenn die Schlacht in Yggdrasil stattfindet?
Antwort: In diesem Fall wird die Völva getötet, da sie sich nicht dorthin zurückziehen kann, wo sie sich bereits befindet.

Zwergenhäuptling (I) und Soldat aus Hel (III)

Frage: Die beiden Karten kosten keine Wut, um sie ins Spiel zu bringen? Antwort: Beide Karten kosten weder beim Aufrüsten noch beim Invadieren Wut.
Faktisch kosten sie also niemals Wut.

KAMPFKARTEN

Friggs Gunst (I)

Frage: Die Karte sagt, dass ich einen weiteren (anderen) meiner Clan-Werte ebenfalls um 1 Stufe erhöhen darf [erste Auflage] bzw. dass ich zusätzlich einen Clan-Wert
um 1 Stufe erhöhen darf (falls möglich, nicht den bereits erhöhten) [zweite Auflage]. Was passiert, wenn ich diese Karte beim Plündern von Yggdrasil nutze oder wenn ich durch das Plündern 5 Ruhm erhalte?
Antwort: In beiden Fällen darfst du einen beliebigen Clan-Wert erhöhen. Bei allen anderen Belohnungen musst du aber einen anderen Clan-Wert erhöhen als den, den du durch das Plünderungsplättchen erhalten hast.

Heimdalls Sicht (I) und Tyrs Herrschaft (I)

Frage: Heimdalls Sicht sagt: „Diese Karte hat denselben ST-Wert wie die höchste gegnerische Karte.“ Tyrs Herrschaft sagt: „Deckst du in einer Schlacht eine Aufgabenkarte auf, darfst du sie als +3 Kampfkarte behandeln. Wie verhalten sich diese beiden Fähigkeiten zueinander?
Antwort: Wenn der Besitzer von Tyrs Herrschaft eine Aufgabenkarte aufdeckt und entscheidet, diese als +3 Kampfkarte zu nutzen, dann gilt auch Heimdalls Sicht als
+3 Kampfkarte, vorausgesetzt, die Aufgabenkarte hat dadurch den höchsten ST-Wert.

  Lokis Gift (III)

Frage: Wenn zwei Spieler Lokis Gift (möglich mit der Erweiterung für 5 Spieler) ausgespielt haben, wer erhält dann die Karte(n) vom Sieger?
Antwort: Beginnend mit dem plündernden Spieler erhält der erste Spieler in Spielreihenfolge die Karte(n). (Spielt also der plündernde Spieler eine solche Karte, erhält er ggf. Karte(n), ansonsten der gemäß Spielreihenfolge als nächster folgende Spieler.)

Lokis Gift (III) und Tyrs Tapferkeit (II)

Frage: Lokis Gift sagt: „Gehörst du zu den Verlierern, nimmst du alle Karten, die der Sieger ausgespielt hat, auf deine Hand.“ Tyrs Tapferkeit sagt: „Gewinnst du eine Schlacht, darfst du je 1 Wut bezahlen, um beliebig viele deiner ausgespielten Karten zu behalten.“ Welche der beiden Fähigkeiten hat Vorrang?
Antwort: Die Fähigkeit von Lokis Gift kann nicht durch Tyrs Tapferkeit verhindert werden. Tyrs Tapferkeit kann nur verhindern, dass ausgespielte Karten regulär abgeworfen werden.

Lokis List (I)

Frage: Wenn zwei Spieler Lokis List ausgespielt haben, wer erhält dann die Wut vom Sieger, falls dieser nur 1 Wut hat?
Antwort: Beginnend mit dem plündernden Spieler erhält der erste Spieler in Spielreihenfolge die Wut. (Spielt also der plündernde Spieler eine solche Karte, erhält er ggf. Wut, ansonsten der gemäß Spielreihenfolge als nächster folgende Spieler.)

In Blood Rage, each player controls their own Viking clan’s warriors, leader, and ship. Ragnarök has come, and it’s the end of the world! It’s the Vikings’ last chance to go down in a blaze of glory and secure their place in Valhalla at Odin’s side! For a Viking there are many pathways to glory. You can invade and pillage the land for its rewards, crush your opponents in epic battles, fulfill quests, increase your clan's stats, or even die gloriously either in battle or from Ragnarök, the ultimate inescapable doom.

Two things set this game apart: 
1) Straight-forward mechanics but varied strategies.
2) Simply incredible components.

This game looks and feels awesome.  It forces players to compete from the very beginning and ramps up very nicely.  It's easy to teach and still rewards experience.

I feel the game is very good, but not the most spectacular game ever in comparison to the hype it received. The miniatures for the game are everything, which Blood Rage has amazing ones, but the rest of the components leave a little to be desired. Small cards, and decent, but fairly thin player boards, but they get the job done.  The design on the board is functional, but a little drab for my tastes, still it looks good, and definitely better than anything I could design. 

The game itself is just fun at the end of the day. Eric Lang produced a solid area control game, with card drafting and hand management combat system. I'm always drawn to games that don't rely on just dice rolling to resolve combat, and this game does a really nice job with the system presented here. Plus there are many different strategies to take, that even if you are getting destroyed in encounters, you can go the Loki route, which wants you to sort of sacrifice your warriors for Glory(VP). A really good, and overall short play length, for this style of game, gets two thumbs up from me.

Sadly, I can't say the same for the expansions for Blood Rage, since they leave a lot to be desired. The "expansions" are basically slight modulations to the core rules, which barely put a dent into the game, as far as new mechanics are concerned. But because of this, it's not a bad idea to include them in someone's first play of it, Blood Rage is due for a nice big expansion that adds more to the game. Maybe new monsters to recruit, a new map, artifacts or sacred weapons players can get that alter their armies, or variable player powers. At this point, Eric Lang has assuredly moved on, from this project to work on more things, but man I hope he revisits this one again.

Now a Rant, not for the game per se, but CMON in general:
I'm not to keen on CMON's business model. Every big game they publish is kick-started almost always being over-funded, and I feel the people who don't fund get skimped on content, such as the inclusion of a 5th player, expansion that non-backers will never see, etc. They did this with Xenoshyft as well. But Blood Rage I think didn'tsuffer too badly, because almost all of the content can be purchased nowadays outside the KS, unlike Xenoshyft(legendary items and Heroes) and Zombicide Black Plague(literally everything it seems). I personally hate KS exclusives, but I understand having a few select things, like metal coins/components, thicker boards or wooden bits instead of cardboard, but taking out mini's or semi-expansion content should solely be a timed exclusive that becomes available later. Just saying the fear of FOMO is ever present in so many CMON games, please make these things less exclusive - how about exclusive molds, or varied artwork for KS backers, or limited edition box that can hold everything you went all in for. Meanwhile I need to fork out $100+ just for the Fenrir model and card, which is just uncool. Look I don't hate CMON by any means. The bring out some amazing  games and have designers who are very talented, but I feel the hype from their miniature-based games garner a ton of hype, and can inflate a game's cost down the line, the more ridiculous the miniatures become.

By Eric Lang. 3p, 4p or 5? Expansion needed for 5p. A DOAM game with a draft-and-pass phase, card-based combat, bluffing and area control. Categorized as having simultaneous action selection because of the draft-and-pass phase, but the action selection occurs later and isn't simultaneous. Some people have said this is primarily a draft-and-pass game. The draft-and-pass phase causes players to know most of the cards that will be played, so I searched for complaints about a lack of surprises in Blood Rage, but I found no such complaints. In fact, some people who prefer Blood Rage over other DOAM games (e.g., Kemet) have said they prefer Blood Rage specifically because it has more surprises. If I were to play this with 3p, 4p or 5p, I would try using the 2p rule of drafting 2 cards at a time (/thread/1809584) because there would be more surprises, and I prioritize surprises over balance. There is moderate in-game text that must be read from small cards in hand and on the table. Tech Geek Gamers' first session (/video/138456) includes major rules mistakes. Board Crazy's session (/video/138782) and Tech Geek Gamers' second session (youtu.be/zgS1yLqVIkc) show gameplay that doesn't seem as exciting as some fans have claimed. Also, I doubt my gaming group would enjoy Blood Rage because we've disliked every draft-and-pass game we've played and some members of my group dislike reading text on small cards. I'd consider trying Blood Rage if it weren't so expensive.

I have played Blood Rage 4 times. I owned the game, but have removed it from my collection. The only pro to this game is the minature, very nice quality for the price. That's why it gets 2 stars.

However, I will never play this game again. It gets so many things wrong. Part of my dislike may be from thinking this game was area control going into it and being a big fan of area control and battle games. The area control element has no impact on if you win the game. The battle element has no impact on if you win the game.

This is a drafting game, that's it. You can lose every battle and win the game. You can control the board at the end of every round and lose the game. This has everyone who I have played with annoyed, even the winners. If you like card drafting and luck, this game is for you. If you like strategic planning, the heat of battle, negotiation, and the thrill of victory: stay away or play with alternative scoring.

Game based on the nordic mythology were different tribes of vikings compete for being the most glorious one. I was very surprised when I first play this game. The owner was explaining the rules and I was thinking "man, these rules are too easy. This game is going to be boring" but, during the game, my interest started to grow as I find myself with several options every turn, and the things to do, were to put the minis, which card to play, what strategy to follow, and just with some very easy rules, the game came alive very smoothly and making a lot of sense. It is true that the mechanics could be applied to very different themes, there is not huge relationship between the vikings and what you do during the game but, however, it is fun to play and there is an adequate strategy and planning that has to be done in order to win.
And then, the great mechanic of the game, clearly, is the Ragnarok. When you first listen about the rule that after each era one location is going to be destroyed because of the Glorious Ragnarok, you think that better get off all my minis from that place, but when you realize that dying under that fireball is, in fact, a great way of earning points, it is when the fun starts.
One of the concerns that I have heard and experienced is that there are some special miniatures that break the balance of the game. I do not think that the differences are that big, but it is a point to be considered.
Positive:
1. Great artwork
2. Great miniatures
3. The Glorious Ragnarok
4. Several strategies are possible
5. Easy to play
6. Drafting mechanic
Negative:
1. Some characters may be too powerful
2. Some expansions should be used
3. Some KS miniatures are no longer available

Arguably I shouldn't be rating this since I only played the first third of a game. But I think I got a decent idea from just that much. I also think it's helped by my rock bottom expectations going in, but I really enjoyed what I played and it seemed like the rest of the game would build on it nicely. When the first round was over I really wanted to keep playing to see the rest of the game.

The card drafting works well, in particular the hands are large enough and the player count is small enough that you'll see hands multiple times. I'm always happy with deterministic combat and it seems like you can do some cool stuff with well timed pillages in terms of moving people around. But I think my favorite thing was the customization and differentiation of the factions and the way that affects the way different players will play. I'd have really liked to see that through to the end to see how the different players developed and what kinds of power combos you could end up with. But already in the first round I was seeing some nice differentiation. I think my first reaction to it was to give it an 8, but between the components and just wanting to hedge a bit I'm going with a 7.5.

In the back of my mind I'm wondering if part of the reason I was as impressed with this game as I was is because it's not a genre I have much experience with. Recently all the new euros I play just feel like more of the same and that hurts their ratings, whereas Blood Rage feels fresh to me, but I can't really say in any qualified manner if it actually is doing anything particularly unique.
This was a fine game, though not really my cup of tea. I don't get all the hype surrounding it though.

Blood Rage is not the usual type of game I enjoy, but it's hard to deny it is good at what it does. It can run a little slow at times, but even in the downtime the tension is off the charts. It also has some unique mechanics - chiefly that losing battles can be part of a valid approach.

It's not all to my liking, though. While there are some events one can plan around, the game is mostly a game of tactics, with only the board state and some upgrades - all of which may or may not be useful based on the cards one sees in the draft. Personally, I enjoy a bit more long-term planning. The game also shrinks the board as advanced tactics and powers appear. This might add tension, but it kills the ability to focus on building an engine - something else I like doing in games.

If this sounds like the kind of game you like, you are gonna love it. But even for those who usually don't enjoy this sort of game, it's worth playing.

Initial Rating: 4.0 (November 2015)

I wasn’t expecting much from Cool Mini or Not´s Blood Rage but still the game managed to disappoint me.

The rules are uber easy to grasp, the theme is cool except for the fact that you don´t feel you are a Viking fighting epic battles. Blood Rage is a control area game with some drafting between turns. For me the game fails miserably. 

First I have heard that the game offered “exquisitely” hard decisions in the drafting because all the cards were equally powerful but from my point of view that’s not true. The drafting is obvious in all regards, perhaps at the very beginning you don’t know what to do but after you have a couple of cards you need to pick the cards that complement your previous cards and game situation. It takes seconds to decide this because it is very obvious which card is the best one. I also feel there is a huge unbalance with the cards, for example the monsters can affect the game in a huge way (as the Orc in the first Age) and it is pure luck if you manage to draw one of the powerful ones, there is only one card per monster so it falls to the players to balance the game. To summarize I found the draft to be obvious and the cards to be unbalanced. Lots of uncontrollable luck here.

Second, the area control in Blood Rage fails for me as well because often, the loser of the combat wins almost as many points as the winner, it feels out of sync when a player does this, that is, it feels weird when a control area game allows and rewards a player when they lose control of an area. Besides purposefully losing battles doesn’t fit thematically in any combat game.

Blood Rage also features the (hated by me) “attack the perceived leader” and it lends itself to king-making situations. I heavily dislike both of this characteristics. In our game, it was a foregone conclusion who would win it even before the second age was finished, so it has a rich-gets-richer problem as well.

Blood Rage uses the same core mechanism that Chaos in the Old World (limited number of action points) from the same designer (Eric M. Lang), but the gameplay is a lot easier. When I play Blood Rage I feel I’m wasting my precious gaming time because the decision are too obvious, the game too shallow and its length way too much for what it offers (around 2 hours). I was expecting a heavier experience but the game is much lighter than I had hoped.

As is usual from Cool Mini or Not, the game components are amazing. The miniatures are unbelievable gorgeous and look great on the table. The art is very good as well and that’s the only positive I have to say about the game. Cool Mini or Not´s games usually follow this formula, they are gorgeous, incredible looking games, but sadly, they are also ultimately empty games. I’m clearly not their intended audience. I feel that if the game was regular looking it would not have the success it has today, that is, they put a lot of effort on the outside while the inside is very mediocre.
 
It is a very expensive game.

Bottom line, I know I´m on the very small minority, but I dislike Blood Rage. I feel the ONLY thing the game brings to the table are the marvelous miniatures, everything else fails for me. It has obvious decisions, it is a shallow and light game, its game duration is way too high for such a simple game, it has lots of uncontrollable luck. I would play Chaos in the Old World any day over Blood Rage. Way overrated, I already sold my copy.

Fun miniatures war game. Some degree of luck with card availability.  Great component quality. The monsters which special abilities are super fun to handle and deploy and the plastic ring system for sharing monsters in the pool is quite genius. 

Where blood rage shines is that players do not win simply based on succeeding in combat. Instead, players must strategically draft cards and plan their moves to manage their available resources (i.e. rage),to complete quests, and perhaps even lose in battle in order to gain glory points for being in or returning from Valhalla. 

There is luck element which is mostly (but not totally) mitigated by card drafting. For instance a monster upgrade is drawn and kept by the original player the chances of it being passed to the next player is quite low. Similarly, a player may not be able to get a quest card, or a high-numbered battle card, if those cards are retained by the original recipients of the cards.

Six plays in over a three month period, and I I find this game just does it for me. 

Looks? Yeah, obviously. Interaction? In spades - you can't play your own game in isolation, you absolutely have to consider what the others will do as without a doubt it will affect you. Tension? Deciding which cards to pass on can be agonising, let alone which actions to take at which parts of your turn - timing is crucial. Euro-efficiency-mongering - getting the right card combos can be huge, allowing you to really fly. Fights? Oh yes, combat is not scarce or optional (see Scythe), and you had better know which fights to pick and which to avoid. Sneaky? - just check out the Loki cards, the opportunities for turning bad into good are immense.... Man, I love this game.
..............

- Very fun, looks great on the table, not too difficult to teach, plays fairly quickly considering the scope, but not so fast that you feel like it definitely needs one more round.
- Haven't played it with 2 players, but I do have the 5 player expansion. Recommend with 4-5 players. 3 can be king-makey, and I expect 2 will suffer from runaway leader.
- I love all the monsters and upgrades, but you have to balance these in the draft. I find this decision process really interesting... I really want this ability, but I know I'll be able to pull off this quest, and that battle card is awesome too... Decisions decisions.
- I also like the timing elements. When to push, when to plunder, etc. You want to do things in a particular order to be as efficient with your rage as possible, however you're often pressured to do things out of sequence to take advantage of an opportunity or prevent someone from throwing a spanner in your works.

This game is fun and exciting.  The theme is well-done in the art and mechanics and there are a few different strategies to play.  This game has a lot of really powerful actions players can take, and after 5-10 plays, I suspect there are a few cards a player nearly always wants to pick if they have the option.  On one hand, this makes the players feel powerful and the game more fun and exciting, on the other, it can lead to big swings and a little less importance for playing well all game.  Personally, while I appreciate Blood Rage and am definitely willing to play it again, I tend to like games that are more "battles for inches" instead of the "battle for miles" that is Blood Rage.

Blood Rage scratches an itch I don't have. A game that achieves its design goals quite well yet I care neither for its parts or sum.

I'm not a fan of card drafting, card combos, special powers, or compounding abilities toward bigger badder moves. I find the game is largely about the draft and moving up the 3 tech tracks with the board as a stage for these things to play out. Early scoring is small and secondary to moving up the tracks and gaining upgrades toward bigger scoring opportunities in round 3. 

I'd suggest drafting/buying cards Dominion style (the game is essentially deck-building/hand mgt from age-to-age) but I doubt it would significantly alter my feelings. As it is, drafting prevents AP and downtime but at the cost of increased luck into a very significant part of the game.

I understand why it's popular: shiny bits, fantasy theme, euro point maximizer underneath; ultimately a familiar song with a new arrangement. It feels like 7 Wonders and Cosmic Encounter but played out on a board with Viking dudes. I bet the Dice Tower crowd is nuts for this. 

A funny aside, despite all the shiny chrome I never really felt the theme. Instead I found it easy to ignore in favor of maximizing points. But hey it's a euro with a lot of chrome. Neither good or bad.

Was a bit skeptical at first, but boy what a great game. Easy to learn, needs attention to drafting and can be difficult to catch up the first player. Nevertheless, I had fun playing the game so mission accomplished.

It’s fun. The huge swings in the board state that typify a round of Blood Rage create a sense of constant upheaval that suits the game’s setting. The much ballyhooed minis and Frazetta-esque graphic sensibilities live up to their billing. Like a lot of drafting games, your progress up the learning curve is predicated on remembering what sorts of cards are available from round to round. Though not a gateway game in the usual sense, Blood Rage may be a good first step into the world of heavier, dudes-on-a-map strategy games for those who are curious about the genre.

After one play: Was a rough first game where I was pretty lost for the first two rounds but managed to score some points in the third round. Would love to play it more but was less enamoured with the drafting mechanism than I'd hoped. I do expect the enjoyment to increase in future plays.

Edit after a second play: Was doing much better, got the drafting a lot more, but was had my plans thwarted twice by events I didn't anticipate due to my inexperience. I was a little frustrated at the time but was immediately thinking of the next game after the game ended.

Edit after a third play: Ok, I love the game. The drafting really clicked this time, with me attempting to go for a Loki strategy but diverting to keeping as many dudes on the map as possible in the third age, leading to a really high (and winning) score. I also managed to stay out of trouble, not overextend and stick to my gameplan. Rating it a 9 for now.

Much simpler than Chaos in the Old World. CitOW has a much more sophisticated set of interactions among powers and spells and requires players to be much more pro-active about checking one another when they surge for the victory. Blood Rage feels more like a conventional Euro in that players are most interested in building an engine to amass points for victory and strategizing from the draft how best to power their engine. Personally, I prefer CitOW (which has more "story" to it), but Blood Rage is a perfectly adequate substitute for those who want a more teachable and less violent theme.

As an aside, I would recommend letting new players know the possible variety of battle cards and having a reference card for the monsters (so no one gets an unfortunate surprise).

The mechanisms and special skills intertwine smoothly and offer plentiful tactical choices whilst needing a strategic build of your clan. I would have preferred the game with cubes or standups instead of the miniatures but I'm an old curmudgeon.

Probably my favorite game, such that I rate it a 10 even though it is clearly an imperfect one. Balance issues are significant enough that the draft mechanic isn't enough to counter the luck involved with getting the right 1st pick or 2 card combo. This game is more often decided during the draft phase than it should be, but even so it is one of the most fun games you can ever play while losing. Winning feels great. but even getting beat can be hilarious at times. Almost reminds me of Cosmic Encounter or something in that way (which is a crazy but somewhat apt comparison overall).

Blood rage is one of my favorite games. It's easy to teach and everybody has a blast. I love the miniatures and have fun playing it at all player counts (debatable I know). LOVE THIS GAME! Finally got around to picking it up a couple weeks ago and do not regret that decision. Now if only I could trust myself to paint those minis... which are the best I've ever owned!

I avoided the game for a long time because of the KS hype and the FFG-style artwork, though essentially it is a family-style euro with Ameritrash thematic trappings. This is a big draw for many, but for me it is more of a liability. The game itself is mechanically sound, it works. It is fun, combat is quick and decisive, and there really is room for truly skillful play. I know this because thus far I have lost by so many points that I am intrigued to keep trying. On my second play I was lapped on the score track!

Great game! Area control with a bit of a twist - losing soldiers can be a GOOD thing. Love that. The monsters are very cool as well, though it's easy to get lost in trying to get them over proper strategic planning. Lots of fun.

I dislike this game for the same reasons I dislike Cthulhu Wars - Action Points determine what you can do and there are cards/powers in play which not only make you lose AP, some even steal them creating a huge swing in available actions making you lose half a turn while somebody else keeps taking actions which breaks the game in my opinion. Great production. Lots of strategies. Beautiful miniatures. Highly recommended.

Hope you are okay with losing a battle because of an opponent randomly having a +5 strength you didn't know about. I don't know about you, but that's what I call "fun" and "strategy". Aside from that, the board is ugly and the gameplay is "meh". Games from Eric Lang bore the shit out of me. I don't get it. #HypeTrainAway!!!

JASE (just another euro)? How about JAELG : Just Another Eric Lang Game. Can the guy design anything without area control as a primary mechanism?
One of the most fun games I've ever played. Amazing minis. Challenging gameplay decisions. I just can't wait to play it again and again!
Can't get enough of this game! Looking forward to getting the expansions into the game.

When looking at EL’s progression I can see something of CitOW and Rising Sun here. Blood Rage is a good game, but it doesn’t quite rise to the spheres of Chaos in the Old World. On the other hand it also doesn’t dive into the torpor of Rising Sun. The excellent action point system comes directly from CitOW and as the players are at the start of the clan tracks in the beginning it starts rather interestingly. Even with only three rounds the game however starts to drag a bit towards the end if there is even a hint of AP proneness in the air. I do like the whole Loki concept balancing the game and offering another approach to gaining glory. On the con side the balance is cracking towards the end of the game with huge point swings especially thanks to clan tracks. The game also suffers from the Langian syndrome of the cool things being the least useful if your aim is to do well.

The many comments about the minis are spot-on: probably the best board game miniatures ever made. They are stunning.

The game is fun. I enjoyed it even though I don't really think it's my kind of game. I'm only unsure of whether it has long-term replayability.

This is a masterpiece: a Euro game dressed in a thick enough layer of AT theme to please both crowds. I love the drafting, the combat system, the multiple strategies, the tracks and the upgrade cards. I'd love to have a bigger pool, so that not every card would come up every game. One nitpick is that the game seems much bigger, much deeper and more complex than it really is: this is one step up from 7 Wonders, not much more than that. And without the minis, this could be a 25$ game, and play just as well.

I was surprised how much I enjoyed this bloodbath. The combination of Nordic mythology,  raging Vikings, and miniatures isn't one I would normally seek out, but I'm happy I overcame my skepticism and played. The depth of strategy is wonderful, the interaction between players is intense, and the theme is completely engaging. Ragnarök is coming, so get a copy now!

Incredible combination of mechanisms held back by a few miscues. Drafting and combat are a stand out, leading to interesting choices and meaningful decisions. Monster miniatures elevate the game simply by being on the table. Requires both expansions, and some Kickstarter exclusive content to make multiple paths to victory viable. Questionable artistic decisions around female clansmen mars an otherwise spectacular production. Core entry for anyone interested in the hobby.

From a new player's perspective this is yet another game in the FFG cards-and-creatures mould where action economy and synergies are the be-all and end-all, and the game really rewards you if you get it right, and really stomps you if you don't know what to expect. You may think you're drafting goodies but in reality you've already lost, or maybe someone screws you over with a take-that effect while someone else is running away with the win. I'm kinda indifferent to the theme and minis, but I guess they make it easier to assess parts of the game state. Still waiting for a chance to finish a game of Chaos in the Old World...

Fantastic game in every sense of the word. There is no better game to just get into and immediately become engrossed in the theme and gamplay. Amazing minis, great board art, easy to teach yet hard to master.

Loses a half mark for there being far less viable strategies than there appear to be, but otherwise an amazing game.

I love this game. The theme really shines through, you're a viking, so you're either with Odin and want to die in Ragnarok, or you're with Loki and are just messing with people front and center, whole battling it out with people.

The game has nice area control mechanics, being tight. And it also features a tribe construction through drafting that's very satisfying.

It is deep in strategy and not very noob friendly, but I do push it to the table whenever I can.
I cant win at this game! Still great however. Great theme and diversity in play types to win.
El Grande en versión eventos y vikingos, sobreproducción superlativa sin nada nuevo.

This is an outstanding game that currently gets outshined by Rising Sun for me. The games are very different in what they deliver though. I feel like BR has a bit of an issue with a tendency of players being completely locked out of a game by a single bad decision, which RS fixed and added more strategic layers with less "dafuq" RNG moments. If you're looking for variance through deception and mind games, get RS. If you prefer quick action and variance through a little card-driven RNG, get this. Chances are that if you own both, you'll have a preference and one will see significantly less play. I feel like both are on the same level of strategic depth though and both are excellent gateway games into the heavy stuff.
+New notation chart+

Excellent balance of thematic and strategic game design: card drafting, Resource (Rage) spending, and deterministic combat. Really high Production value with some of the best miniatures in the industry.

Tactical optimization over three ages. Some combos are much better than others, so knowing them and beeing able to draft respective cards is key. Even falling back in the first or second age is not too importan, since the last age pumps out fame (victory points) like a beheaded vikings spilling blood. However, that also means that leading with fame in the first two ages is often kind of meaningless. All in all, never dull though.

What I like about this game is it fixes the snowball effect of conflict games by introducing the Loki deck so the losing players gain things so they don't fall behind. The winner also loses his combat card so others are more likely to win the following clashes. The drafting is quick but super meaningful since you are focused on your strategy and trying to block other peoples combos. As people get stronger you feel like the game will drag on but there are less spaces because of Ragnarok so it evens out. Highly recommend this game!

2017-03-03 - 7.5 - Finally I managed to play this game. I liked it, however not as much as I could expect from the hype. But still quite a bit. I think that second game can be better, as I know what cards can do. 
It's mostly area control game with fights, which I would like to be a little more exciting. There is not many ways to change number of figures in regions otherwise. 
I like that there are few ways to gain points and you can focus on your individual strategy, but other players still can mess with your plans.
I think I would like to own it but rather from a trade than a shop.

2017-11-04 - 7.5->7 - Is it a big drop? Not really. I just played again and like other games I rated with 7.5 a little better. This one is good too and sometimes it's really nice to jump onto one another. It's fine with 3 but better with 4. I guess the game is a little better as players have some picture what the cards can do and what you can expect.

2017-12-06 - 7->6 - I feel I always rated this game higher than I felt about it, probably because of all the hype and high expectations. It's fine, but I prefer Nexus Ops to have a quick fight with miniatures on a map and Bunny Kingdom to have an awesome drafting experience. This one is OK, but I will get rid of it eventually.
A more accessible version of Chaos in the Old World. Better theme also. However, drafting is lazy design and Loki is overpower.

Quick playing combat filled game that plays from 2 to 4 players (5 with expansion).  It involves card drafting and card effects that can really swing the game, so experienced players will beat newbs.

I've played two card drafting games now, this and 7 Wonders.  I haven't done well in either.  I have a hard time remembering all of the cards when I see them and can't really envision how the cards will impact play while I'm drafting, so I feel surprised when I get demolished by some combo that another player used.  I think the rating will probably go up as I learn the cards and understand the strategies more.

While the game does have mitigating measures for losing battles (if you have certain cards), you can fall behind pretty quickly and not be able to recover if you suffer heavy losses.  Other players have to beat up on the leader to keep the game close.  I'm not really a huge fan of that either.
Only got to play it once so far.  I don't really like drafting, but it was still fun.

This game is a blast. I love the card drafting mechanic and based on how cards are dealt, your strategy can vary wildly game-to-game. Combos can be huge and runaway scores with a few players isn't uncommon, but it is still fun to battle with everyone. The miniatures and boards are stellar as well. I also love the theme and artwork. Battling may not be for everyone, but seeing these figures clash on the map is always really exciting - especially when people keep adding more units to the battle and going all in. It is definitely one of my favorites. I just wish I could get it to the table more. Four players seems ideal, but I would not play with less than three.
Wow, that was a lot of fun!  I'd happily play again.  A great theme and wonderfully executed.  The plastic figures really elevate this game.

Ve hře Blood Rage se 2 – 4 hráči (s rozšířením maximálně 5) utkávají v nelítostném krvavém boji o slávu. Během tří věků (kol) budou vylepšovat svůj klan a snažit se nasbírat co nejvíce vítězných bodů, které se získávají primárně bojem. Výhra v mohutné bitvě na život a na smrt udělá na bohy dojem. Ale i ti, kteří statečně padnou, se dočkají ocenění. Jen záleží na tom, ke kterému bohu se přikloní. Dalším zdrojem bodů jsou úkoly s cílem ovládat určité provincie nebo naplnit Valhallu svými padlými. A v neposlední řadě se na konci každého věku některá provincie zhroutí a zanikne. Válečníci, kteří zde padnou, jsou opět odměněni slávou.
Un juegazo que no aburre nunca.

One of my favorite area control games. The card drafting at the start of each Age feels super tight. There are so many different strategies to implore. You can be sneaky with Loki-esque trickery, or you can go heavy on quests.

Fun game with various strategies formed from drafting cards. I like how there's no dice to determine combat results and that you have a good idea what cards other people have from the drafting. Biggest issue is trying to remember what other player's abilities are whilst also managing your own goals.

I suspect the 'death' strategy is probably the easiest as it's harder to stop someone from losing a fight. Tip: don't draft too many expensive cards as you'll exhaust your rage to quick.

Whilst I enjoy it, there's something that stops me from loving it. Can't say it's the luck element in what cards you draft as there are a lot of awesome cards and you will always have good ones to pick. The direct conflict maybe?

So, is it a hybrid or a pure Euro? It's not easy to answer - it's like a theme-driven Euro that has a strong AT feel. It also seems to have a strong runaway leader problem until players gain more or less the same experience level; after that, multiplayer leader-bashing might help stopping runaway leaders. The game is quite a good fun area majority stuff but it's rather cruel as only clear winners of that area gain anything while the rest are punished hard(removed from the board).
This, combined with the simultaneous card play during area majority 'fights' make it less of the pure euro many claim it to be even though its mechanism elements all can be found in different Euros (mostly about drafting and area majority, a bit even worker placementish). Still, it's quite enjoyable and I guess it's even better when beginner's mistakes aren't made anymore.

After playing it a second time with years between it, I realize that it's better than I've thought. I enjoyed the drafting mechanism and the different possibilites. Have to play it more often though to learn the cards and combos.

june 2016: Last month I decided to treat myself to a big box, epic, Ameritrash style game and I decided on Blood Rage.  I've played Blood Rage three times now and I can state with certaintity: I am absolutely crap at this game. I don't just lose when I play, I get obliterated. The game really doesn't seem to suit me, hence my lower than average score. I've racked my brain as to why the game and I don't click and have come to the following conclusions.

1. Blood Rage is predominantly a card game. Yes, it has a board and yes it has crazy overproduced miniatures, but the game is all in the cards. So much so that if anyone decided to make a cardgame version of Blood Rage, it would need little tweaking. Card games aren't my strongest suit. I am a better strategic player than I am a tactical one. The card drafting at the beginning of each round is highly random. Only extensive knowlegde of the cards and memory of what your opponents choose can slightly mitigate this luck. My knowlegde of the cards isn't good enough, but every time I loose I've lost to players who've played the game for the first time. So card knowlegde can't have been the only factor.

2. Blood Rage is a tableau builder. The player who quickly builds his or her tableau has the edge over other players. And that edge can be very hard to catch up to. In my opinion the game suffers from a runaway leader. Twice have I lost the game because a player with better stats became unbeatable by the other players. End game scores where the winner has twice the points of the other players have been the norm around here.

Some people are under the false impression that Blood Rage is a mixture of a eurogame and an ameritrash game. I really don't agree with that. Blood Rage is an Ameritrash game through and through. The six cards you get each round aren't enough to think of a strategic gameplan. In most eurogames, your strategy is yours to choose. In Blood Rage, more often than not, you're at the mercy of the cards you've been dealt. It is too random and chaotic for a eurogame. And after Eldritch Horror, Imperial Assault and  X-Wing, Blood Rage has started to put me off these American style games. I probably won't get rid of Blood Rage yet. I'd like to see how my thoughts on the game will change after I've played it some more. But Blood Rage has go to be the biggest gaming  disappointment  of 2016 for me.

Tactical Skill check with great theme.

+ I like the fast turns (single action).
+ I like how each player customizes their clan throughout the game.  
- The theme is superficial, with card names that don't have much relationship with the effect.  
+ The rules are simple enough. 
$ The game feels smaller than Clockwork Wars, because of the relative lack of flavor, because of the more restricted mechanisms. 
+ Quick battles.
- I can't help thinking that this game (even the base game) has almost too many minis: I prefer games with fewer minis but more game/flavor/richness (e.g. Clockwork Wars). I feel that they add a bit too much fluff to the game.
$ The game feel is essentially that of a series of short combats for quantitative improvements (the 3 tracks), with a constant interaction between players (who compete for the territories), and a progressive customization of each player.
+ The terrain is small enough that many battles happen, with an interesting center that can be joined from everywhere (important for reinforcements), but territories that remain a bit far from each other that positioning is meaningful for battles (too far and you can't reinforce).

Overall: a lean-enough game of many small battles, with limited flavor. Almost a dry euro-like game of battles with some chrome (minis, some background but not much flavor). Well done, though, but not "wide" or flavorful enough for me to be in awe (contrary to Clockwork Wars).
The theme is great, the mechanics smooth and the many possibilities fun. This shot straight to one of my favorite games.

Blood Rage ist im Grunde genommen ein Mehrheitenspiel mit einem Karten-Draftmechanismus.
Das Spiel wird über drei Zeitalter gespielt. In jedem Zeitalter erhalten alle Spieler jeweils 8 Karten, wählen eine davon aus und geben den Rest ihrem linken Mitspieler. Das geht reihum so weiter, bis jeder Spieler 8 Karten gewählt hat, wovon jeder nun nochmal 2 Karten abwerfen muss.
Nun geht es der Reihenfolge nach, dass jeder Spieler aus den gewählten Karten eine als Aktion spielen kann. So bringen die Spieler neue Einheiten aufs Brett oder erhalten Verstärkungen/Monster/neue Anführer/neue Fähigkeiten). Diese Karten müssen mit Wut, der Währung des Spiels, bezahlt werden.
Auf dem Brett können ebenfalls Aktionen ausgeführt werden, wie z.B. die Einheiten von einem Ort zu einem Anderen zu bewegen oder ein Dorf plündern, was einen Kampf gegen die anderen Spieler hervor ruft. Gefallene Krieger werden nach Walhalla geschickt wo sie bis zum Zeitalter Ende bleiben.
Am Ende eines Zeitalters verschwindet eine Region aus dem Spiel und alle Einheiten auf ihr gleich mit. Für diese ruhmreichen Gefallenen erhalten die betroffenen Spieler Ruhm (Siegpunkte).
Siegpunkte kann man außerdem für gewonnene Schlachten gewinnen und als Sonderpunkte für diverse Dinge, wie z.B. fürs Sterben der eigenen Leute, wenn man denn die passende Karte vorher ausgespielt hat.
Ich finde das Spiel gar nicht mal so schlecht, allerdings gefällt es mir auch nicht so gut, dass ich es nochmals spielen wollen würde. Es hat sehr viele Gemeinsamkeiten mit 7 Wonders, wobei 7W sehr viel einfacherer zu spielen ist.
Mir liegt das Spiel auch nicht sonderlich. Es passieren mir immer wieder kleinere Fehler, die aber große Auswirkungen haben. Rein von der Optik her ist es auch nicht mein Fall. Das Cover zieht mich nicht an und die Miniaturen sind zwar beeindruckend, aber Minis sind nicht das, was mich zum Spielen verleitet.

Playability: Blood Rage plays absolutely fluently, there are no rules questions. Especially the concept phase at the beginning works very well. Blood Rage lives on his "Area Contoll" mechanism. The Skillen of his group earlier recall a Eurogame. But you have to constantly weigh up what his teammates are doing. Influence on the game: except in the phase of drafting this game has no luck. Even if Draften has minimized the happiness party so far. that you can only draw one card at a time and then the batch is passed on. (Similar to 7 Wonders) Game charm: I love this game and I like the Theatmatic. This is super implemented on Blood Rage. The game is fluid, has little luck, always finds new combinations and is constantly interacting with his teammates. Blood Rage is really great for four or more players, but also works fine with the two of you. the game is unfortunately not well balanced to play a fair game.

Initial Impressions: Basically met my expectations but not my hopes, as in it seemed as good as I would imagine from reading the rules, but not as good as the current 8.38 rating + good reviews + finally a good thematic Viking game + factoring in the high cost. As I thought before playing the card drafting doesn't really fit thematically with the game at all. Also I wish there was a little bit more differentiation from each of the smaller unique monsters, some are just stronger versions of others. 

Besides the drafting and the area control the order you perform your actions appear to be pretty important. Also you must choose very carefully which battles you intend to win, as using your high value battle card early can easily screw you over later on if you're not careful. Therefore, this game is more strategic than I thought it would be; the game definitely does not play itself after the drafting phase.

You don't use all the cards each game even for a given player count so there is a little bit variability there.  Also the locations of which bonuses go in which locations and which locations are destroyed create variability too, but we'll see if it's enough as I play this game more. There are multiple ways to score in winning battles, completing quests, purposefully losing some battles with the right set of cards, and getting your units all destroyed by Ragnarok, so at the very least I should be kept busy for a bit in choosing which of those I want to focus more on.

Runaway leader appears to be an issue as if you win battles/complete quests your stats will go up which will allow you to do more stuff later on. 

EDIT: Somehow I've gotten family members who normally can't play anything heavier than Lords or Waterdeep to able have a basic understanding of how this game works. If this proves true for other groups this would be a great boon to this game as being a game I can use has a "next-steps" game without me having to compromise in my game choice. I sometimes wish the combat cards worked similar to Kemet where unit destruction is not directly tied with winning battles, although this would make the strategy to get your units destroyed significantly weaker. 

EDIT 2: There are a lot more cool card combos than I initially anticipated, the core mechanisms of the game have continued to be fairly easy to understand (though there are quite a few less prominent rules that are easy to miss), and I think this game worked very well with 4 players.

The rules are very simple, elegant, and easy to understand. Considering that, the level of depth is surprising. The draft mechanic in particular ensures that a peak skill level is hard to reach. The game also goes very differently every time even after 10+ plays.

The game is always exciting. No matter how well you seem to be doing and what cards you have, you still have to be careful or your plans could get blown apart. So risk management is a very central aspect of the game.

It's not perfect though. A few of the seemingly viable strategies are not strong enough in the end, because the cards that they rely on are too expensive for their cost. Then again no game is perfect, and this is still one of the best games in my books, so 10/10.

A internesting euro, masquerading as a war game.  The game begins with a card draft.  You then spend rage to take actions on the board or with cards.  Some actions don't require rage like plundering a town.  

The game is incredibly deep.  On the surface, it may seem that aggressiveness will pay in a game called Blood Rage, but actually, it often comes down to timing.  The temporal element of this game is a big factor, and knowing when and where to act is important.  You can spend a lot of cards opposing someone and getting nothing for it.  

The game can be swingy as well.  Odin's throne can really help someone in last place and turn the whole game around for you.  

But on the whole, the game is great.  It may crack my top ten.  Fun family game as well but the kids need to be at least 12 or so to play.

De los mejores juegos que he tenido oportunidad de jugar. Combina varias mecánicas, control de áreas, draft, cumplimiento de objetivos y enfrentamientos, todo con el objetivo de acumular la mayor cantidad de puntos de victoria. La temática de Vikingos le viene bien y las minis son una chulada. 

El único inconveniente que le veo es la editorial CMON exprime la cartera con tantas expansiones y Blood Rage no es la excepción, nunca he calado alguna pero que el kickstarter tenga otro 40% del juego es una gran tristeza para la economía personal.

By and far my favorite board game.  Plays great with both my friends as well as my family.  The card drafting phase is a great way for players to select which upgrade/combat/quest cards they want per round as opposed to just a random draw.  

Customizing your clan of vikings is a very neat and rewarding aspect of this game and is governed largely by the card drafting phase.  Players often have to make critical decisions between taking combat cards or upgrade cards.  The addition of the large monsters with added combat bonuses is also a great feature.  

Depending on which cards you choose, you can customize your clan to actually benefit more greatly from purposely loosing battles by using the Loki cards. There are also combat cards that can be played that completely negate the effect of the other players combat cards, steal rage for losing a battle, or make players throw away their combat cards and be forced to select another.  With all of these options available, you never know how the outcome of a battle will play out until it is over.  Many times I've seen small clans beat much larger ones due to proper play of combat and upgrade cards.  Many times in this game, the player who wins the most battles is not the player with the most glory (victory) points at the end of the game.

Overall, this is the best amerithrash style game that I've ever played and I can't recommend it enough.

Blood Rage is a fast-paced slaughter game that will certainly satisfy the most bloodthirsty players. Although none of the provided Viking clans possesses unique abilities, the replayability is quite high as each season players gain 8 randomly chosen cards from which they pick one for themselves and then pass their pack of cards to the player on their left, at the same time they receive another pack of cards from the player on their right and this will repeat up until the moment each player has 6 cards. The cards you pick heavily affect your strategy throughout the game although you will easily end up changing your strategy entirely for each season. Honestly, Blood Rage is a bit too combative for my taste and your units die like flies very often and then return to your reserve from Valhalla so I do not care for my units while playing BR as much as I do when playing Rising Sun or GoT for example. But that's just my point of view, beside that I can't think of anything else I could criticize about Blood Rage.

Overall, I am very happy with this purchase. This has hit my table probably more than a dozen times, and has converted myself and my friends into gamers who are willing to play longer, deeper games. (I avoided longer games before purchasing this since I didn't think I could get my friends to play such things more than twice)
I will note that for my game group, plays take about 1:10 per player, which is definitely longer than what it says on BGG and the box. However, I'll admit that my group is perhaps fairly AP prone and not totally focused. That said, the length really does not take away from the game. I am rarely bored, as the decisions that other players make matter a great deal to me and my strategies, so I am definitely involved when someone else is moving. Perhaps I am even trying to manipulate them out of attacking me (or perhaps into it). 
In terms of mechanics, I think the game is very solid. I think every game I have played but lost, I can imagine how a different set of decisions would have swung the game in my favor, which implies that the luck factor in the card drafting is not so significant. There are paths to victory implied in the game design, but ultimately you have to play with what comes up in your draft, so I often find that mixing and matching strategies is a better approach. That also makes it more replayable, as you won't be playing the same strategy every time. After all, you might love to go all in on battles and annihilate everyone else, but if you aren't seeing any of the heavy battle cards, you aren't going to win in Ygdrasil, so you'll have to adopt some other strategy.
It can be a bit punishing: one large lost battle can really cripple you, since the battles are all or nothing. On the other hand, you can always know if you can guarantee a win or not, so you can usually choose not to commit your forces to their doom. (I recommend going over all the battle cards each age before the draft. It's simply not fair if you know what exists and others don't. Other cards, like the troll, should also be pointed out). 
PROS:
-- drafting is fun and keeps each game fresh. It's funny how unsure everyone is of their choices as we go round
-- limits on troop numbers in (most) territories adds a lot of strategic element to a game that would otherwise be dominated by cards. You can win battles with inferior forces and cards by smart placements and some misdirection, as well as pick off some enemy troops from a superior army.
-- short, one action turns keeps everyone involved
-- Elegant design. Though a game with a lot going on, it is surprisingly easy to teach, as there are more "exceptions" (in card form) than there are rules. Compare to Scythe, which I hate teaching, because there are just too many little details to go over. 
-- Heavy player interaction, but with limited ability to truly team up on anyone, makes this fun and social, but keeps things pretty civil. 
-- different paths to victory, but there still certainly seems to be a focus on winning battles and controlling territory, as befits the theme
-- cards that let you gain from losses can keep the game tight even when you aren't able to dominate
-- every turn is a meaningful decision
-- 3 age structure really works to give the game a sense of momentum
-- theme mostly works nicely. figurines are nice, though I don't really care for minis. Cards are nice. Board could be prettier, but at least its good quality.
CONS:
-- The name. It's over the top. Whenever telling people the name of it, I give it extra ironic dramatic flair because I just have to embrace how ridiculous the name is.
-- female clan: why do they have to be basically naked? I think it would have made more sense to make them well armored. Also, half the soldiers of each clan could have been female, since there were two molds anyway, but fine, I guess viking clans can reproduce asexually, I don't know. 
-- some cards seem rather useless. Sure, they won't get drafted, so it doesn't break the balance, but it would be nice if every card was at least valuable for some strategy. (that card that steals two glory when you lose, I'm looking at you. That will almost always be a net gain for the other player, usually by a spectacular amount). 
--  Could be I haven't figured it out just yet, but it does feel like the player who drafts the strongest battle cards and certain upgrades (masters in arms, anyone?) wins the majority of time. But I suspect that better play could mitigate that advantage, and the three drafts does make it rare for one payer to get all the best battle stuff (though it can happen).

An average Dudes-On-The-Map game with lots of playability due to the numerous abilities and monsters to use in the game.  It's surprisingly very easy to teach since all the information is both on the cards and playmat.  In terms of pacing, it plays pretty quickly since you are able to do only ONE action per turn instead of multiple (more board games need to do this).  The game ends shortly after the climax and doesn't overstay its welcome.

However, I don't feel the "need" to own this game.

The first glaring problem with the game is the simple fact that you need to know the decks inside out to play at any competent level.  Otherwise, the game just feels like you are along for the ride with no real direction to follow.  I've seen experienced players take advantage of their neighboring newbies because of newbies didn't realize that passing certain cards to him would just make him powerful.

Another problem is the numerous effects that make it hard to decipher the game state.  Throughout the session, you will encounter card effects that seem to give you points for doing almost random thing such as dying, or other people dying, or losing a fight, etc.  Unlike the younger brother Rising Sun, there doesn't seem to be any focus within the game.  You have vikings, stuff happens, and you score points.  In Rising Sun, while there are effects that give you points, the game still forces everyone to be on the same page about gathering monsters, building strongholds, and taking over areas.  

With all the faults, the game does have sparks in its design.  It plays quickly, the downtime is minimal, and it's very easy to comprehend the core basics of the game.  Unlike many other games, I feel the expansions like the Mystics and Gods actually hurt the game instead of improving it.

Mystics of Midgard

I bought this game, and to my delight, my 27 year old girlfriend loves it as well!  We play mostly 2 player and although it's not as fun as 3+, we still find it very fun and balanced as a 2p game.  The minis are SO fun to paint and admire.  Deliciously frustrating for the loser, and glorious for the winner... and both want a rematch ASAP.  Well worth the $75 CND I paid for it.  

Finally, I altered the clan sheets (very good quality card stock).  Using some tin snips and some metal ducting material ($7 at a home reno chain), I cut squares slightly smaller than the clan sheets, and taped them securely to the back.  Now we use magnetic (custom made from simple magnets from a dollar store) markers to track current rage, starting rage, glory/battle, and units on the clan sheets.  No more "accidentally" moving the stock cardboard pieces by bumping the table :D

Strongly recommended overall!

Rating based on 4 players.

Chaotic but pretty fun. I like the general mechanics of this, but it's *incredibly* swingy, and most of these swings are due to hidden goals (Quest cards). The changing powers of the players was too much to keep track of for me as well. As a result of both of these, it felt like that even though we were interacting and fighting on the board, I had little impact on what others could do because our goals could be entirely different--for a game about warfare, it felt strangely solitaire-ish, and I don't know how I could have done much better. 

There are lots of potential ways to score (it can potentially get a bit point salad-y), but the gameplay is simple, straightforward, and it does feel nice pulling off a good combo and getting a slew of points.  

The minis are very nice, but the difference between the leader and the regular warriors was not big enough.

Certainly not a bad game, and I can see how some of my complaints would lessen with repeated plays, but while I enjoyed my play well enough it's not my cup of tea.

Man, am I glad I finally caved. This game is AWESOME! The drafting is fun and grueling, the combat is straightforward yet exciting and the game has that epic feel. This is a euro-hybrid made even better with awesome components.

Excellent theme, and the drafting in this game is probably my favorite feature of the game, it's small, but yet so important and exciting. However, i don't really care for area majority games, and blood rage sends the Analysis Paralysis into overdrive, way worse than Five Tribes does. Blood Rage is a good game, but every decision is mentally exhausting, and this game can overstay its welcome, sometimes cutting it close to three hours.

Not a bad game by any stretch, but felt a lot emptier, less thematic, and mechanically dry than I expected. The lavish production doesn't add anything and the gameplay feels like it would suit wooden pieces better than plastic.

I enjoyed the drafting and powerful card combos, and while I appreciate the smooth game flow, play length and simple-enough mechanics, it felt like the design had been streamlined to the point that the 'soul' of the game has been polished right out of it. At no point did I feel like I was raging, pillaging, fighting, or dying for glory, just manipulating the game state to get points.

Comparisons to Chaos in the Old World are accurate on a mechanical level (power points, turn structure etc) but this doesn't have the thematic richness, nor does it involve me as much in the gameplay.

2020: A former Top 15 game for me which simply couldn't get past its balance issues. A good example way Lang's games never quite live up to the idea of how well I will like them.

I really want to love this game... I do. The miniatures are fantastic, the theme is great, and the mechanics are straight-forward and easy to learn.

There's a fundamental issue with this game, however, I noticed it during a playthrough and haven't revisited the game since. I found that it's way too easy for one player to become overpowered, early on. I can't pinpoint HOW, exactly, but it might have to do with certain players being able to leave all their pawns on the board in between rounds, while the other players have to use action points to move theirs back on at the start of each round.

I don't know... after one round I got into an argument with my brother about it, and we ended up TALKING about the game/rules longer than we ended up PLAYING the goddamn game! I'd like to revisit it, but there's other stuff that I already KNOW I'll enjoy playing... and at the end of the day that's what makes for a good game.

Edit: I recently played this again with some friends, and I'd be willing to bump the rating up to a... let's say 6.8. There still are some fundamental problems with becoming overpowered way too quickly, but with some homebrew rules, you could really make this game work.
