Absolutely love this game.  Will not go into too much detail about gameplay, but essentially the game consists of two phases.  In the first you draft cards from the given round's deck, taking a card and then passing the rest to the next player, who in turn is doing the same.  In the next phase you take turns playing your cards, placing your army, and doing battle over the different regions of the board in order to gain rewards and further develop your clan.  Rinse, repeat.  As things progress you get more powerful cards, the game board becomes smaller as regions are destroyed, and more battles inevitably occur.  There are multiple paths to victory, so the most powerful army is not always the winner.  

Pros: 1) Easy to learn, but lots of strategy.  2) Quick gameplay, yet still deep and rewarding.  3) Contents are high quality.  Great sculpts.  4) It's very FUN!  (Isn't that what's most important?).

I owned this game, then sold it, then reacquired it in a trade. I've played it quite a few times throughout that period, and here are my general thoughts.

The game is fun overall. I love the clan progression, the drafts, and the theme. Components are generally great (although CMON boxes are terrible across their line; what's up with that?).

What I don't love is the swingy nature of the game, and what feels like some balancing issues favoring certain strategies. It's a little hypocritical of me because there are other swingy games I do like, but for some reason it affects me here more than in other situations. Perhaps because in those games I take gameplay with a grain of salt, and here I'm expecting a more "serious" experience? I'm not sure. 

I'm also not a general fan of the CMON Kickstarter FOMO strategy, and it bugs me that exclusives from their campaigns are impossible to get for a reasonable price. It leads to them doing lame campaigns like their digital one they just ran where the figures are functionally the same, but not. Seems ridiculous to me.

Rant aside, the game overall is a great game and worthy of its high ranking. Ultimately, it's probably just not for me.

First impression is very good.
Several ways to win.

Let's see:

- Fantastic theme.
- Awesome artwork and miniatures.
- Balanced and interesting gameplay, with lots of different ways to earn points and, because of that, several possible strategies to win. The player interactivity is also very good, and the combat system is easy and intuitive but still requires quite a bit of thinking.
- A lot of replayability because of the many elements that shape each game.
- It's not too hard to learn but it's complex enough that you never truly feel like you completely know the game.
- It works perfectly with any number of players (although more players will give you access to new cards and monsters).
- Luck influence is almost non-existent, only being noticeable in the draft at the beginning of each era.
- The game isn't too long, specially considering how big it is. Also, you never get bored while playing it because it's very dynamic and you have to pay a lot of attention to what the other players do.

Even after 7 plays this game is still great, and seems to get even better. There are only a couple things that keep it from a 10 for me. First, I think there are a couple dominant strategies that cannot be simply out-played if the player happens to get the right cards. Additionally, I really wish there would have been some more included cards in the box that would have made repeat games a little more fresh. You definitely see the same cards in each successive game, which on the one hand enhances the strategic aspect, but the card combinations definitely feel finite.

Overall, it's amazing. The components/theme/artwork really tie everything together. The rules are intuitive and the turns are fast yet strategic. Definitely recommend.

The mechanics of Blood Rage are quite interesting and I usually quite enjoy the game when I play it. But after 5 plays (all 4 player games), I find that I tend to leave the table unsatisfied and frustrated. 

I think the main issue I have is that there are too few cards - I've seen them all, and they fall a bit too neatly in a few synergistic groups. I think that adding more cards to the total pool (but keeping the number of cards players keep) would really make the game more interesting to me, as you would not know exactly which cards are in play - and there would be a greater chance of "new" strategies appearing, rather than different people picking from the 3-4 existing paths every game.

Then again, I've found myself often thinking "Huh, maybe it's time to give blood rage another go...?".

There are aspects of this game that I do not like. The card draw randomness (despite the drafting) is one. The meanness (at times) in the interaction is another. King-making is yet another. The left-right binding is a problem as well. However, I still keep coming back to this game time and time again. It has enough going for it (interesting card mechanics, personal powers, power+card drafting, variable scoring conditions), area control mechanics, the interesting combos one can unearth over the course of a game despite having played the game quite a few times, all packages in an aesthetically pleasing package and tight mechanics mean that I would almost never turn down a game of Blood Rage.

(6/21/19) = So, approximately 10 plays and I am starting to feel a bit saturated with the game. Perhaps the expansions can freshen things up. Playing with the same group a few more times also should make this pretty interesting. Still an 8/10 for me. But might move down if those subsequent plays do not meet expectations. I am also never going to want to own this game I suppose (I hate all those minis and cannot see myself every really wanting to get into them. would have liked the game more actually if they had just used abstract representations for warriors and monsters and if the tear-down was faster).

Blood Rage is a bit of an odd one for me. I can't say I'm ever really excited to play it, but it usually ends up being a good time. It's a great beer n' crackers board game, that gets better as you get more intoxicated. Watching friends make fatal errors of judgment is fun in its own right.

This game suffers from a bit of an identity crisis however. Though its weigh is medium or even medium-light in terms of mechanisms, the depth of strategy in the game is anything but. It took me many, many plays to feel like I knew what I was doing, and actually assemble some sort of strategic combo. The good news is that there's a lot of variety to strategies that work, once you figure out how to make them work. 

Also, the game is hilariously unforgiving. This would be a negative for most games, but here it just adds to the experience.

My feeling is just...meh.  This game was totally overhyped.  Maybe I would have enjoyed it more if I hadn't expected so much.  The minis were pretty great looking, but I was unimpressed by most of the other components for the price.  The game and player boards just felt cheap, and I was not that into the artwork.  

Besides that, it wasn't horrible, just not my kind of game.  I had heard that there were a lot of euro-y mechanisms but between the draft and the battle it felt little more than glorified rock-paper-scissors.  This might improve with play and knowledge of the other cards in the game, the varying strategies.  But I just didn't find it that interesting.  I have a love-hate relationship with area control games.  I often don't mind games with some majority bonuses, a very typical euro-type scoring, but games that rely heavily on area control, descendants of El Grande, have never been my favorites.

I would play it again, and I think I could enjoy it a little more, having better expectations going in.  But overall, I just didn't feel the game stood out like I hoped it would, after so many rave reviews.

I backed this one a while ago and it arrived in good order not too soon after it was due (delivered in October with a September projected delivery time); for a KickStarter that’s practically an early delivery. Mrs Fish liked the look of the large packing box (yes, I went all-in for the 5th as well) and decided it would make a dandy Xmas gift for her husbandman. Which it did.

Anyway, over the Xmas break I unboxed the goodies (much to the delight of the Little Fish), read the rules and got pretty excited about the game. From what I could see it was everything that I hoped, add on excellent production values including some superb miniature sculpting and I was keen as keen could be to get it onto the table of honour.

Fortunately, it was pretty easy to find other interested parties and I managed to get in a couple of games at a local games meet-up the first with the base set and the second with both the Blood Rage: Mystics of Midgard and Blood Rage: Gods of Ásgard expansions (discussed below). I also took it along to Cancon and taught it to three new players which was good.

The base game itself is a pretty good game, very engaging and one that has a lot of challenging decisions. Starting the round with card drafting is interesting as it gives a player a chance to ‘read’ the play for the next Age and work out what one’s opponents are up to as well as working out what they need to do. Building a decent ‘engine’ is also rewarded as having complimentary abilities on all your cards is very important. These are skills that will come with experience and should add a lot to the replayability of the game.

The game encourages bold play and there are plenty of ways to score point so that a bad round does not necessarily put a player out of contention. So, in short, a winner a keeper and one game I’d like to play again and again.

A nice accessible game with great components.  The card draft gives each round a unique feel and presumably increases variety from game to game.  The actual turn structure feels both tactical and strategic.  You have an idea of what you want to accomplish for the whole round and each turn presents you with a nice amount of gaming tension as you try to determine actions that will allow you to achieve your overall goal.  It works really, really well.

Puntos fuertes: Miniaturas con mucho detalle. Mecánica de draft bien implementada.  Arte muy cuidado, original. Muy bien tematizado.

Puntos débiles: La calidad de los tableros individuales es muy mejorable (cartulina fina). Las miniaturas pequeñas al ser de plástico vienen algunas dobladas. Demasiado despliegue para la duración de la partida a dos, al menos.

Conclusión: Buen euro disfrazado de Ameri-trash. Juego muy bien ambientado de mecánica simple. Para un público iniciado en los juegos, pero quizá algo corto para jugones. Hemos de reconocer que aquí tenemos opiniones encontradas. Pep cree que es un juegazo y Nany que ni fu ni fa.

This game just does so many things right. The "dudes on a map"/area control/combat is awesome. The drafting is awesome and makes the engine building very very satisfying. How your engine builds makes the combat even more exciting. And the "multiple ways to get points" aspect means that even when you are getting slaughtered in combat, you could still be racking up points thanks to your hidden objectives. And you can start to see how these elements all connect and flow and make for a very satisfying and fast paced experience.

The theme is awesome, the minis are some of the coolest I have ever seen, and this is all just beautiful window dressing on what is one of the 10 best games I have ever played. If you like hand management or drafting, or engine building, or area control, or combat, then you're in luck because this game has a little bit of it all, and no other competitive game I have played combines all of those elements quite as well as this. Hats off to Mr. Lang with this one.

Love the theme. I don't like how lucky you have to be to get a monster in the draft (they get drafted immediately, so if it's not in your first stack then you're out of luck). I also don't see how a Thor or Odin-based strategy would work; Tyr and Loki seem to be the best battle cards. FYI there's this one card that my group has found to be OP (it lets you invade with an additional warrior for free). We've removed it (and have to playtest more), but so far we're enjoying the game more.

My first foray into both area control and card drafting. The game is a lot of fun and, despite the glutton of minis, is actually fairly straight-forward and easy to teach. New players might not fare well compared to those more experienced with the different paths to victory; however the game manages to be fun enough to mitigate the discrepancy in scores at the end of the game.

This is one of those odd games where the discongruencies between the mechanics and theme bother me. It also feels possible that there are a few cards that one should build an engine around, so if you draw those cards, draft them, and can build those engines, you will be competitive, and if you don't draw those cards, you probably won't be. (Hopefully, the number of competitive engines is at least the number of players in the game.)

Me? Buying a game because it has cool minis and a promise from the designer that it will be good? That would totally never happen.

Once stripped from the overproduction and the theming/clothing of a wargame-ish area control game, Blood Rage turns out to be more akin to a victory point salad than I'd like. About everything scores, from upgrading stats on your player board to losing battles (!). There are lots of numbers to get track of, many cards you draft are a bit unexciting, many others railroad you into seeking pre-written personal synergies rather player interaction. If that's your bag, fair enough; just don't expect me to sing its virtues.

Not to help, while I'm usually willing to put a lot of suspension of disbelief into board games, a large proportion of the big scary-looking monsters offer one of the finest examples of ludo-narrative dissonance in the medium; being more often than not a mere "That's it?" passive ability that mismatches the overproduction of their miniature with your unfulfilled desire to wreck the battlefield with it.

Ragnarök is coming to Midgard and the viking clans must prepare for Valhalla. Utilizing interesting gaming mechanics beyond simple area control, players guide their clans in pillaging, battle, and dying for glory!

Braindead, ehm.. brave warriors whose biggest death wish is to go down in a blaze of glory? A PUBG-like Ragnarök mechanism destroying and shrinking the board every round? Epic Yggdrasil fights where everything and everybody gets involved and the winner takes it all?

Blood Rage brought me back to board games and opened my eyes for the trashy side. It's an Euro for sure, still it's thematic, powerful, dynamic and a blast to play. In the best possible way everything is swingy and broken and wombo combo in this game and it feels enormously satisfying to feel the impact and synergies of your actions. 

Behind all overproduced bombast, martial slaughter and stupidly-gory (but not bloody enough) background setting there is a clever tactical and overall mostly balanced area control/drafting game, which I full heartedly love and recommend. Encourages me to start painting my stuff.

Du bist ein Wikinger, der Anführer eines stolzen, alten Clans. Auch wenn der Untergang der Welt bevorsteht, wirst du deine Krieger in die Schlacht führen und erobern sowie plündern, so wie es schon immer deine Bestimmung war. Triumphiere über die anderen Clans und erringe den letzten Sieg, den die Welt jemals sehen wird.
Das Leben ist vergänglich, aber Ruhm währt ewig. Jetzt ist die Zeit, für diesen zu kämpfen und zu sterben!

A masterpiece of strategy, would have get a 10, but i'm not absolutely sure about the balancing. It's also hard for a beginner vs experienced players. Despite that a perfect theme with amazing miniatures and a very good drafting system combined with area-control. Also no diplomatic parts, pure stategic placement and bashing.

This game's aesthetic hides a very complex and amazing area control game.  The aesthetic is beautiful (although the font can be confusing at times).  I love the drafting mechanic, and I don't have a problem with hidden information and cards because, like many games of it's kind, prediction and probability are a part of deciding whether or not you want to build your forces up or engage in warfare.  It is also a style of game that rewards time and plays to learn its nuances and deck powers.  The game is controlled by three ages, so it does not drag on and ends at the perfect time.  I can see where complaints arise about the visible display of points on the score track, but often the game is decided on the final battles where one player will acquire and play that one card in battle and, if they win, get an end of game bonus that manages to inch them into the winner's spot!  Cannot recommend this game enough.

Solid, well-balanced game with simple rules but nonetheless complex interactions. Very different experience whether going for a 2-player or 4-player game. The theme is great, and you really feel like a pillaging mob going berserk until the end of times. The difference in scoring can be significant and not knowing the cards is a big disadvantage though; therefore, you may want to give good advice to new players and educate them on the implications of their actions... otherwise, they may easily get brutalized, leaving them with a bitter aftertaste.
Great gameplay. Amazing minis. If everyone knows how to play you could play this in 40 minutes. Would love to try the expansions to add a bit more variety in gameplay.

From its components I worried that Blood Rage was just going to be another Kemet, (which I despise). Not so!

BR's smart integration of its Norse theme creates a balance in strategy from each card reflecting the personality of God bestowing the Gift. Some give brute force, some are crafty, some favor the underdog. BR's philosophy of honor through death constantly clears sections of the board and relieves the calcified territorial battling that occurs in other area majority games.

The worst thing I can say about BR is I detest its Kickstarter funding. Having discovered the game late there is pretty much no way I'll ever get my hands on the KS Stretch rewards which makes it feel like I'll never get to experience the full game.

BR is very combative. Scores usually have a wide spread, with crushing losses that can be dispiriting for players.

Oh, and I think the name is dumb. Blood Rage doesn't conjure to mind a viking game. It's predecessor, Midgard, was a better title.

A very nice dudes-on-a-map game.  Gets the job done quickly, encourages strategic thinking and tactical flexibility.  Well done, Eric.  So why the 7?  Because without the gewgaws of the admittedly beautiful miniatures, it's an average weight dudes-on-a-map game.  And this leads me to a bigger issue...

This game is being lauded by reviewers who received their $100+ game as a freebie.  I'm glad that these people appreciate this game and are taken in by its design, both as a game and as an object.  But these people are influencers, and these people are conveniently forgetting that for us mortals, us people who don't get free games on demand, we have to pay $100+ for a game that could have been distributed for ($20-60) without the bullshit.

This game is a 10 at $50, and a 7 at $100. I am clearly not CMON's target audience -- it's that simple.

Really fun game. Best at 4 so won't play it often but really enjoy it for what it is.

(+) Relatively simple game to play
(+) Fast pace - can play a 4p game in 90min
(+) Crazy, fun combos of action cards
(+) Customization/build up; each player starts the same but by the end of the game everyone's strategy and abilities look totally different. I love asymmetry, and the way it is done here is neat.
(+) Cool minis and powerful monster effects
(+) Strong theme. Game just looks and feels cool to play. 

(=) Some strategies seem better than others, especially for new players (i.e. Loki)
(=) Kind of wish cards were full sized, but flagging as neutral since it helps keep the player boards smaller


(-) Lot of small rules questions that the rule book does a bad job explaining or clarifying
(-) Snowbally nature and potential runaway leaders

It's Chaos in the Old World with less asymmetry and no dice. I like the asymmetry in CitOW, but not the dice; so I like this one! It has aspects of area control but with simultaneous-reveal battle cards, which seems to be the rage (no pun intended) these days; I like that too, although I'd prefer if the army strength mattered just a tiny bit more.

Monsters seem very powerful on the board - perhaps overly so? But dominating on the board is not a sure path to victory. I'd like to play more.
+ les 4 monstres exclusifs KS

All the production stuff has excellent quality: illustrations, minis, graphic design, cardboard...

It's the best blend between eurogames and tactical ameritrash I've seen lately. It's clearly superior to Chaos In The Old World, as many people claim. The draft mechanism is key, but so is the order of your actions, and adapting to what other players deploy and do on the board... It manages to create tension and maintain it.

On top of that, the gameplay is quite fluid and and it has an good game lenght of around 90 minutes.

Not everything is perfect in Blood Rage, though:
-> Runaway leaders (and players with no hope of catching up) will happen often
-> Some cards seem overpowered :-/
-> Some cards interactions are not covered in the rulebook
-> Not enough cards of each era to reinforce replayability.

Overall, it's a very interesting mix of american and euro games. Able to produce both great and dull games.

Enjoyed this much more the second time I played it. It's satisfying to pull off strong combos of cards. Drafting is always a card mechanic I enjoy, and having three totally different types of cards in your hand makes it interesting. [English] Don't be fooled by the most fantastic miniatures of board gaming history. Blood Rage is the ultimate Eurotrasher. This game has got the best from both worlds: A cool viking ameritrashy theme with a whole lotta euro mechanics. This game integrates my three favorite mechanics of board gaming of all time (Draft, Variable Player Powers, and Area Control) in a majestic way. The main downside of this game would probably be that does not scale well (it is not very good with 2 players). Besides that, a fantastic experience.

[Español] Que no te engañen las mejores miniaturas de la historia de los juegos de mesa. Blood Rage es el Eurothrasher definitivo. Este juego combina lo mejor de ambos mundos: Una genial temática vikinga muy propia de los Amerithrash combinadas con un montón de mecánicas propias de los euros. Este juego integra mis tres mecánicas favoritas (Draft, poderes asimétricos, y control de área) de manera majestuosa. El único punto negativo que tiene el juego es que no es un juego muy divertido a 2 jugadores. Aparte de eso, una experiencia fantástica.

This is a solid area control game, and the deck build/draft system is neat.  You can mess yourself up but can also turn things around with a card you did not really want to begin with.  My main problem is the tribes are all the same and the main fighters are all the same, just different molds.  I really think some variable player powers or units that had different roles could have made this game even better than what it has become.

Despite the amazing artwork and fantastic miniatures, make no mistake: This is a Eurogame through and through, not a thematic wargame of any sort, despite appearances. As a matter of fact, the primary mechanics at work here are rather dry card-drafting, area-control, and action-point allocation.

Whether you like these kinds of Eurogames or not, it is hard to appreciate a game that more often than not has wildly differing scores at the disappointingly anticlimactic end; the winning player commonly ends the game with around 100 points more than the person in second place, with players in the middle of the pack rarely ending with scores even within 25 points of each other. Needless to say, almost every player I have shared this game with came away disheartened and frustrated.

Obviously, this game has now been sold.

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (6/8 -> 4)[/COLOR]

[i]I had reservations about Blood Rage and they ended up being right. We played a few more times and I just didn't find the game fun. It really is as simple as that, Blood Rage is my least favorite dudes on a map game I've played to date. I normally love drafting in games, but not in Blood Rage. I didn't find the different god cards you draft to be that interesting; most of the synergies were very clear cut and didn't require much thought to execute. Combat resolution was okay, but I much prefer the card based system Kemet employed versus this one. Blood Rage failed to connect all the different mechanisms into a cohesive game play experience. 

I know I am in the minority, but I really don't get the hype surrounding Blood Rage. Is it really the minis? Either way, Blood Rage is a game I'll be avoiding in the future.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]- Battle resolution is great, you know the strength of each unit but being able to play a card adds uncertainty to the outcome of the battles and adds to the strategy of deciding when to pillage. 
- Relatively quick to set up for this type of game (my biggest gripe with Kemet).
- Not sure how fun the game is with three, I think it may need four to be more competitive, but I'm only two plays in so this may change.
- Mini's are nice, but the warriors all suffer from droopy weapons. Personally I find the mini's from Kemet to be far superior, even the smaller warriors.
- The other components are lackluster, thin player boards, tiny cards and bland board artwork.

I'm not sure where I stand with this game yet, I definitely need and want to play it more. I've played two 3p games with my kids and both have been absolute blow outs. I know part of this is just learning the cards and combos in the game, but I also feel like three players may not be the best player count. I can't even imagine playing with two. I also keep thinking that we are playing things wrong, but I think we got most things nailed down for the second game. It would be nice if the supposed FAQ they are working on would get released. 

As it stands my kids are having fun so it'll continue to get played, but I'm not sure if it'll remain in our collection in the long term. Of course I could also see us really enjoying the game a lot more once we understand the nuances of the game play. Right now if I had to choose I still prefer Kemet, but this game is much easier to set up and teach. I guess time will tell.[/i]

After three games, I believe this game is too much luck-dependent, random and unbalanced to please me.

The cards global distribution and the cards received are the two randomness factors. You can somehow mitigate this by knowing all the cards in the game and by memorizing the cards received and passed... But a "memorize all the cards game" is not my kind of game. 

Some cards are definitively more powerful than others: Those who knows the game well will know which cards are worth keeping and which are not: They can build a much more effective strategy than the other players.

It is no surprise to me that the player owning the game has won the three sessions played... The fact that the winner had more than four times de VP of the loser clearly reveals the balance problem.

心得:
賣互動的遊戲
重點在輪抽能不能組合你要的組合技
行動階段則稍微想一下決定執行順序即可
要被圍毆好像也不容易
人多可能比較熱鬧
但是每個城鎮的大小限制又讓人多策略性會降低
算是還不錯的遊戲
模型真的是大加分
規則:
*主圖板跟其餘圖板放置，放一個綠色邊緣的掠奪標記在中央世界樹獎勵面朝上，其餘隨機開著放在其他八個省份，8個滅世標記隨機三個文字面放在時間版圖對應位置上，把末世標記放在該回合的滅世標記指定省分。2/3/4人時隨機拿3/2/1個滅世標記放在其對應省分上，該省分遊戲不使用，根據人數移除對應卡牌再根據牌背洗勻放在時間版圖對應位置上，世界標記紀錄回合
*每人拿一個種族版跟所有模型還有底座，所以模型跟船都裝上該顏色底座或帆，計分標記放0，種族標記放在個人圖板的三個計量軌第一格，跟怒氣值6的位置，隨機起始拿起始標記，每時代結束會左傳
*遊戲進行三輪，每輪有六個階段，利用時間板塊紀錄
1..輪抽階段 之前輪的手牌先放著，然後發這時代的手牌每人8張(第一場遊戲第一輪可不輪抽)，輪抽每次留一張，值到保留6張，剩下的棄掉(2人時一次選兩張)
2.行動階段 怒氣值移到起始格(能力可能讓你增加)，由起始開始輪流動作，需要支付怒氣的就支付，怒氣到0的玩家自動pass，選擇pass的玩家怒氣也自動歸0，在所有人pass或是所有未被毀滅的省分被成功掠奪後，行動階段結束
>侵略  支付等於單位力量的怒氣值放單位到任意外部省分(中間不行)的空村莊上，船要放港灣，放領袖不花怒氣，場上單位數上限等於你圖版的號角數
>移動 花一怒氣移動一個省分(港灣不行)所以村莊的單位到另一個省分的其他空村莊上(包括中間，中間沒單位限制)
>升級 支付升級卡力量值(左上)並放到對應圖板欄位，可蓋掉之前的
*如果是單位(領袖，戰士，船，怪獸)升級，可馬上免費做一次侵略動作
>任務 蓋著出一張任務卡在圖板對應位置，沒上限
>掠奪 選擇一個有你單位(船在港灣也可)位被掠奪的省份進行掠奪
a.從你左手玩家開始，輪流可選擇移動一個相鄰此省分的單位到此省分的空村莊上(不花怒氣，pass玩家也可以做，船不行)，直到滿或每人要進來，如果沒有其他單位跟船在此你直接掠奪成功，直接獲得獎勵將掠奪板塊翻面，但沒有分數
b.出卡牌 每個有單位在此的人暗出一張卡(除非沒牌)，一起打開，只有戰鬥卡增加戰鬥力跟效果，每個人把其單位戰鬥力總和(包括卡牌，沒單位也會算卡牌)
c.結算 戰鬥力最高獲勝，平手都算輸，輸的卡牌都收回手贏的棄掉，輸的人移動所有單位到valhalla圖板，發動掠奪的如果獲勝可拿掠奪獎勵並翻面，如果輸就沒事，然後戰鬥勝利的獲得其個人圖板斧頭值得分數
*一個港灣相鄰兩個省份
3.棄牌階段 棄到剩一張，最後一的時期全棄
4.任務階段 打開任務卡，如果完成條件就拿獎勵，比力量的平手算失敗，會加總相鄰港灣的船
5.諸神黃昏階段 拿此回合對應的滅世標記放到對應省分，毀滅面朝上，所有該省分單位跟相鄰港灣船都移動到VALHALLA圖板，並根據時間圖版的獎勵拿分(2/3/4分在1/2/3時代)，然後移動末世標記到下個要毀滅的省份
6.所以在valhalla版圖的模型回手，所有掠奪標記翻回獎勵面，起始玩家左傳，回合標記下左移
*遊戲在三個時代後結束，加總個人圖板的三個能力額外加分(4/5格+10，最後一格+20)，分數最高獲勝

This game flopped pretty hard when my group tried it. By the mid-way point, the winners and losers were already a foregone conclusion, with no real catch-up mechanism available. A few of the cards are overpowered, and the game seems to reward those who purposely lose all their battles — hardly a fun way of playing an area control game.
The draft, the area influence, the powers, just great. It almost got me interested in the Viking tradition that says nothing to me.

Another Kickstarter game I'm kicking myself for not backing. In my defense, this is typically not My Game; it looks conflict-heavy, dungeon-crawly, plus it had miniatures. But oh my god, this is a really good game! Blood Rage has many elements I love in classic Euros: a great Norse mythology theme, card drafting, multiple "tracks" for resources and victory points as the game's deciding factor for a winner. The game's turns are fast and easy to understand; most of your time in the game will be spent deciding whether you should join battles when another player "pillages" an adjacent territory. Blood Rage is a terrific entryway game for people who want a bit more theme and interactivity than a typical Euro. But the game is also great for veteran players because it has a great foundation of solid mechanics and flawless gameplay. Definitely a recommend for everyone! Now on to painting those miniatures!

A nice re-implementation of Midgard. Doing away with all the placement cards turns the game even further from area majority (the bane of fun), and into a game where you're just slamming guys on to enjoin battle in various areas. Battles are won and lost on the cards you play (gained 7 Wonders style at the start of the round). The really nice thing is you can do well in the game by losing all your battles, as there are oodles of ways to gain points when you lose. It's a matter of building a strategy with your card draw, and flowing with it. I'd happily play it again, but I'm not sure continual conflict games have enough in them to keep pulling me back. Entertaining more than engaging.

This game has area control, collapsing territories, card play and upgrades....many good elements. The area control works well and is limited by the zones in a area (once all the zones are filled up, no more units can enter). Territories are destroyed by the Ragnarok in each of the 3 ages; this really tightens up the board and forces players/forces to interact. There are many upgrades, so I can see each game being different. You can upgrade leaders, ships, units, clans, monsters, etc. What you can do on a turn is limited by the amount of Rage you have (which you can upgrade as well). 

One of the most visually stunning parts of the game are the HUGE monster minis. There are 4 included and any player can get them (by spending Rage). 

Overall this is a really fun game. Combat is different, as you only fight if one clan pillages a territory but that's not a bad thing.

Blood Rage is a game in which players create armies and try to take part in glorious battles before the impending Ragnarok ends the world.  In each of the game's three rounds, players first draft a number of cards that provide special abilities, give them access to new units, grant victory points for certain end-of-round conditions, or help them fight battles.  Players then use their limited resources to deploy their units and fight over the various territories, earning points for the battle and bumps on tracks providing income, increases in the unit cap, and increases in battle rewards.  At the end of each round, a pre-determined region is destroyed by Ragnarok, and units left in that region are killed but earn bonus victory points.  While this seems fairly straightforward, a number of upgrade cards provide "perverse" incentives for losing battles, having your own units killed, etc.  I'm a little concerned that such cards may be overpowered in comparison to normal strategies.  Also, I found it was too easy to "camp" regions, as if a region is full of a single player's units, it's almost impossible to dislodge him.  Despite these misgivings, I found this to be a thoroughly enjoyable game, with a wide variety of interesting strategies and gameplay.

Really fun game with lots of great mechanisms, very interesting game with great minis.

In the end this "Chaos killer" was most certainly not. It doesn't actually value most of the ideals that made Chaos such a great game, and completely embraces its euro half. The sides are symmetrical and draft cards from a common pool, so that completely kills the asynchronous beuty of CitOW. The battles are deterministic. The loser can get rewards. There are too many actions that take 0 Rage. Objectives are secret and therefore not only far too easy to obtain but also generate no additional drama or impact on the way the game is played. 

It's got a respectable skeleton. The Yggdrasil area is very good design what with the central nature and the vastly superior rewards. The action pool is still a good design, spoiled slightly by far too many 0 cost actions. The monsters are kind of neat. 

If CitOW didn't exist I might have somewhat of a higher opinion of this game, but as it stands I've seen what can be done with the area-control Euro-trash hybrid and this just doesn't hold a candle.

The buzz about this game will linger in the air for a long time.  Another winner by Eric Lang and certainly the game that made him a household name among board game efficionados.  Blood Rage uses a number of mechanics from card drafting, to area control to card driven combat.  You are vikings fighting for glory before the land erupts in fire and all ends in Valhalla.  But their are many strategies you can employ to gain glory.  Will you be strong in battle?, will you go after quests, or will you submit to your enemy and get glory by dying.  How you play is determined by you and the cards you draft.  Everyone I have played with has LOVED this game.  The artwork is good .. not stellar, but the miniatures are some of the best you will find in any game period!  You have a clan of warriors and a leader but can draft monsters and ships to aid in your quest for glory.  Wow..just wow

Had some very high expectations of this one, seen the extremely high average rating of 8.2 (03/06/2016), but my one play so far was a sort of a bummer. 
First of all: this is a way overproduced (as the warriors could have been easily replaced with simple cubes like in most majority games) sort of majority game. But my biggest concern is: there seems to a certain number of winning combo-cards and if someone has those, there is simply nothing you can do, apart from waiting until the game is over (which I must admit isn't that long). The only way to solve this problem is to know all those combo's and prevent the creation of such a combo, but that requires a lot of plays of this game off course :s

To end, a sidenote: in the beginning I thought that you could win with a sort of losing-strategy (by the Loki-cards who give you an advantage if you lose) and that would be a cool thing. Then after a full game, I don't think it can compete at all with simply being the strongest one and pillage a province. Simply because pillage improves yours stats, which is a big advantage, as it lets you score even more points by winning a batlle and gives tons of end points at the end of the game as you reached the end of a track.

Edit 12/06/2016: Increased rating after second play as Wim proved you CAN win with a losing strategy. It seems harder, but it's great that you can win by losing :D

This is a dudes on the map game, where each player has three stats on their player boards, a limited number of action points, and a pool of units. Players then draft cards which will define their strategies and goals for that round. At the end of the round, a region explodes and gets closed off, making each subsequent round tighter. This game is really fascinating as you explore the ways the different cards and strategies interact. It's also great that combat is only through unit strength plus a single card played, meaning it's diceless. This game satisfies the desire for minis combat and has uprising depth.

Kind of a stripped-down Cyclades, removing many of the finicky mechanics (and, admittedly, some of the complexity and depth).  The miniatures are stunning, the battles are tense, and the rules are fairly simple.  Set up is long, long, long, but the game is satisfying enough to justify the effort.  It is undeniably conflict-based, and that can lead to runaway leaders or players that are left in the dust early in the game, but proper strategy can make losing battles almost as VP-lucrative as aggressively dominating the board.  Plays well with five players (but requires an expansion, which irritates me).  
Probably my favorite CMON game.
Recommended.

Die besten Miniaturen auf dem Markt, grandioser Card-Drafting-Mechanismus, verhältnismäßig leichte Regeln- und obwohl es in diesem Spiel ausschließlich ums Kämpfen geht, ist ein gesundes Maß an Taktik mitinbegriffen. Grandioses Spiel. Vorallem die Loki-Taktik (Punkte für gefallene Krieger) ist innovativ und macht das Spiel so einzigartig. Kritikpunkt für mich: das abrupte Ende der Runde, wenn alle Orte geplündert sind erzeugt zwar komplizierte Entscheidungen, lässt starke Kombos oft aber einfach unberührt, weil sie zu lange dauern würden. Außerdem bin ich ein Riesenfan von Variable player powers, die das Spiel bestimmt nicht schlechter gemacht hätten.

It focuses a little more on combat, but the best part about it, I've mostly played it at 4 or 5 players, is that almost any plan that involves the board will be messed up before it comes around to your turn again.  The chaos makes me happy, unfortunately if you have compulsive planners this means their turns take forever.

As good as Kemet I guess? But tile "shopping" is replaced by cards drafting at the start of every age to form your main strategy.

Unlike Kemet where battles can be initiated just by invading, BR battles are only initiated if someone pillages a province and neighbouring opponents wish to stop the pillage, provided there's empty spots for them to enter the province or they are already in that province.

Wow wow wow! Blood Rage was my personal Game of the Year in 2015 and even more than two years later I still play it as much as I can and still enjoy it just as much as I did the first time! The expansions are not a must-have but they add a lot to the replayability and depth of the game.

Wow! What an amazing experience playing this game! Even though I was seriously trounced, I enjoyed every minute of it.  It's one of the most engaging games I've played in a while.  Even when not my turn, I was constantly thinking about my upcoming turn and trying to deduce what the others were trying to accomplish. 

This game combines many different mechanisms in a deeply strategic way. The drafting is crucial, and, as I found, it's just as important to consider what you're passing as to what you recruit. Giving someone, say, two identical quests can really set that person up for a landslide turn for example. Even the deterministic battle was sweat-inducing.  The battles were simple and victory is sweet when you can get it (and want it) and agonizing when you don't.  

My game group loved it as well...even the guy who HATES card-driven mechanisms in games (and who actually trounced us in our first game)!  It's a game I'm eager to get back to the table, and it likely will despite our infrequent game schedule (1/month) and the size of my collection.

The production quality is top-notch. I didn't get the kickstarter version, but honestly, there's so much in this game I don't miss the few extras that came with it.  I appreciate that the retail version has plenty of monsters and alternative sculpts for the warriors.  There's really no excuse for not enjoying the base game.

Not my jam. 
I appreciate the design, but it feels too Ameritrashy.  Certain ability combos are ridiculously powerful, and once a player gains momentum through card effects the game is over.

I wanted to like this more than I did.  I love Chaos in the Old World, but the balance in this game feels off to me, while all of the cards are overpowered, some are crazy ridiculously overpowered, especially if one of more players are unaware of them, due to them being chosen first before the cards are passed.  I also feel like the crazy powers of the cards overwhelms the board presence and many times the board presence outside of having a presence in a province was superfluous.  This game is still interesting and I would try it again, but not nearly close to the hype for me.
this one and Chaos In The Old World (same designer : Eric Lang) are probably the best in the 'Dudes on a map' genre
over rank.

Got to play this for the first time 4 player, I have to say it was a blast. The game plays fast and smooth and there really isnt enough time for someone to be a passive player. You have to get in and get your hands dirty FAST. Also a lot of games can have that feeling of not wanting to be "the jerk" but this game doesnt let that happen because everyone is attacking everyone is dying immediately and honestly dying isnt REALLY setting you back and in most cases it scores you points if you play your cards right. 

The main point is that by the time the game was over we were all laughing and having a great time. We sat for about 10 minutes just talking about peoples card synergies and how they were able to score the amount of points they did. 

Doesnt overstay its welcome and honestly leaves you wanting to give it another try. Not sure Id be interested in 5 player but 4 was great.

I have only played this solo thus far (first play through before getting it to my game group table) but oh my word does it have potential. I will absolutely, undeniably, LOVE this game. It has almost everything needed. The question is how soon can I have the game group up and running.
EDIT: This game is SO much fun with 4 people. First play through with 4 people yielded some amazing results. Everyone enjoyed the simplicity of the game. Teaching the game required a first age run through, then we reset the game and started drafting. Most of the time during the game the waiting was more on what people wanted to do during the draft. This is where the delay crept in. I would imagine that a second play through would be MUCH faster since people have an idea of what cards are out there. Overall, I would say this was a gem of a game. I did reduce the ranking a little bit (9->8.5) as it kind of felt a bit squishy. However, I may raise it again after playing a few more times.

A most excellent game.  I first tried it at Origins when it first came out but we only had a limited play.  Finally played a full game and loved it. Good to have a cut throat attitude when playing this game.  Great miniatures.  I would buy this game for the right price.

After more than 30 plays Blood Rage still stands the test of time as my number one boardgame. It plays smoothly and relatively quickly for a game of it's weight. The drafting, combat system, and production make this area control game just outstanding. While some games have come close to knocking this one off, sometimes prematurely due to their newness factor, I continue to make sure I play them multiple times to verify, and they always come up slightly short. Just a great game that will certainly go down as a classic in the Annuls of boardgaming history.

This is the game if you just want a game of action and no frills. I own this because I need a breath of fresh air now and then from all the peaceful worker placement games etc. It keeps going and going and everything is about raiding, dying, and destroying :) But it all comes together fantastically with a very fitting theme, and the art compliments it perfectly. Learning the game takes at least one play through, but the rule book is really good and it starts to click quickly, there's just a lot to learn. To me this is a must own, the game stands alone.

This is constantly touted as a great blend of euro and ameritrash gameplay, but I barely recognize the euro mechanics. For me, every second of the game felt like that moment in Yugioh where someone shouts "you've activated my trap card!" Sure, there is little bit of control in drafting the cards at the beginning of each round, but the actual execution of battles is almost entirely unpredictable. You drafted high battle cards? Well, I drafted cards that cancel high battle cards! Bet you didn't see that coming! I won my last game by simply sitting in two zones, filling them up with my warriors, then drafting all of the Quest cards. This is not a good game.

This is one of my biggest disappointments.  I expected so much because people have touted this game as so amazing.  I very much disliked this game.

First, it seemed to have a huge run away leader problem.  If someone is lucky enough to draft some cards that synchronize well early in the game they can jump to an early lead.  If you weren't able to get many upgrades in the first age AND had your troops destroyed during the first age I don't think you have any chance of coming back.  It's just not fun for that player.

Second, the luck of the draw isn't HUGE, but it's definitely noticeable.  There are decidedly better cards than others for each age and if you didn't happen to draft those cards you are going to have a bad time.

Third, the battling is so over rated.  There are too many battle cards in the game for the amount of battling that will occur.  It's too easy to avoid conflict because it's too easy to stack the odds in your favor.  If you see someone coming into your territory and you can't win, just leave.  This is a bit of a simplification, but I don't want to go into all the details to explain this (it'd take too long).

The miniatures are awesome and the components are pretty great, in general.

Ameritrashy game with some Euro mechanics. Card drafting is the central mechanisms and way to individiualize your clan. Combat is interesting and there is a lot of out-thinking your opponent. Key is to discover combos of different cards/powers and also utilize them to score a lot of points. There is certainly skill involved.

Even though it has no dice and some mechanisms are Euroy, this is a pure Ameritrash game to me. Combat and take-that events are such a major part of the game. But this is also a reason, why I think it is a good but not a great game. 

Miniatures are gorgeous and art (especially on cards) is good. In total I understand why this is the game of the year  for a lot of people.

Favourite dudes on a map game that I've played so far. Love the Viking theme, love the fact that it is easy to teach but still has great decision making. Can be argued that you can get a runaway leader problem, it's not too friendly for new players. I'd suggest not drafting with new players as the book says. Fantastic game.

The board gets tight through the 3 rounds and makes for some nice conflict.  I do feel like some of the cards are a bit too synergistic and forces players to draft to block others instead of developing their own strategies.  It also leads to games being outright blowouts in some cases.  It's too fun not to like though.

After reading a lot about Blood Rage, decided to buy the game. Definitely a keeper and a super interesting, strategic board game full with viking themes and great artwork. The rules are easy enough to understand but the game offers a lot of different plays, tactics and strategies and each game differs from the previous one. No matter whether you win or lose - it is fun for everyone playing which is very nice and important. The plastic miniatures are simply great - awesome production level and really help dive into the theme of the game. In my opinion - one of the best and most amusing board games I have played that provides lots of replayability and fun to all participants.

I've only played this once so far, although I expect I'll get to play again before too long. It was a 5-player game, and was really quite a lot of fun. It reminded me more than a bit of Chaos in the Old World (by the same designer), due to the general dynamic of paying to summon units on to the board, upgrading those units to give them special abilities, and having them fight each other, without this fighting being necessarily the whole point of the game. In other ways, of course, it is very different - lacking the asymmetry and the cool alternative routes to victory, but with other elements like the Quests and the 3 different upgrade tracks. Not to mention the crucial card draft at the start of each of the 3 ages, which I suspect between experienced players will constitute the real "meat" of the game. I thought this was an excellent game that I'd love to play again. And the miniatures, particularly the huge ones for the monsters, are very impressive too :)

My favorite game.  Started playing this among many others and 9 months later it is still the one I want to play.  Wish they had named it something else; I find the name alone turns casual players off.

The ability to gain points for warriors killed in battle is fine but  there is a tendency for players to throw warriors away in suicide missions. Whilst the Vikings saw dying sword in hand as the best way to go they usually fought because they were after economic gain, military success and glory. They did not seek futile engagements. As in Germanic warfare, warriors would fight to the death around their chief.

Apart from this minor criticism, the game is entertaining and plays quickly. The monster figures are particularly well done.

The best miniatures I've ever seen. Fun game with lots of action. It's a game about battling for control and to pillage, and that's what it delivers. There's no place for people to hide. Add in the drafting and card bonus effects to make things unpredictable and exciting.

The obvious start to this is that the figures are fantastic. Really detailed and great to look at. The larger monsters have a nice weight to them too. This is, undoubtedly, what will attract a lot of people to playing.

The card drafting aspect is a decent mechanic - it just doesn't work overly well here. Some cards are obviously superb and should always be taken, no choice required. Some are terrible and are easily passed until you're stuck having to take them. The size of these cards is also an issue - why do they have to be so small?

This leads to the most important bit - gameplay. It's an original idea, alright. But it's not really all that good. Area control and fighting, normally a decent concept. The idea of getting points for defeated fighters is unique. But, for a fighting game - it doesn't seem to engross you as actually battling. Throwing men into a hopeless battle, just so you can pick up a few extra VP from their death - doesn't really tie in to the idea the game gives you, of Vikings in glorious combat ending in Valhalla.

The length of the game is also an issue. If you read my reviews, you'll know I'm a big fan of longer games. But when there's not that much happening that I care to track in a game - the longer game just turns into a chore.

So overall, the excitement factor in this game just isn't there for me. It's an OK game that is simple enough to pick up, but would be one I'd have to be talked in to playing again rather than suggesting to anyone to bring it.

To be completely transparent, I expected this to be rubbish after my horrible experience with Rising Sun. Thankfully, it is very different, and shares more mechanisms with its far-distant ancestor set in the Warhammer world. As an aside, CitOW is still my favorite of the Lang saga. I enjoyed Blood Rage for what it is: a strong area control with quaint, if outlandish, mythological Norse themes. Now, here's the sour spot, and from what I can tell it is the hot take—the Loki strategy, though I suppose thematic, is a little bit bogus and oddly hokey, namely because it's so easy to pull off. So you're telling me that the counter play is to play around it until I can suss out who is really gunning for it by the end of Era 1 at the earliest, then just make sure this player doesn't die from me all game? And trust that the rest of the players do the same? And oh I can't refuse to fight them if they pillage in an area I occupy, anyway? That's a one-dimensional and stale conclusion to the meta which will likely cause my opinion of this game to deteriorate upon further plays.

Blood Rage is meh for me. There's nothing special about the drafting of the outlandishly tiny cards. All the "hype" comes from the miniatures, and I am not one to get very excited about miniatures. There is a problem with catching up to the leader; a bad first age means you are almost certainly going to lose the game. Playing against experienced players is a nightmare, and you'll almost definitely lose then too. While I'm criticizing, I also think spending "rage" as a resource is a little tacky.

Aside from this, the art is pretty good, and the combat system is interesting. I'm a fan of the board slowly shrinking turn after turn, squeezing the players together and forcing more interaction. The center space fights also add a lot of tension. These are really neat mechanics that are enough to make me want to play at least a few more times. Not a game I own or want to own, but I'll play it with the right people from time to time.

(+)

5) The viking theme fits well and every gods has his specialty
6) The random distribution of pillaging rewards offers variability and interesting choices.

reddit 2015 recommendation
"Blood Rage deserves a spot on this list, for a couple of reasons:
It nails asymmetric gameplay, allowing each viking clan to create their own identity through the course of the three eras.
It plays very fast, oftentimes having an era end before you expect it, meaning you can't mess around
It encourages aggression to the highest degree, very much like Kemet, meaning there's no time to sit back and watch or build up - it's time to fight right out of the gate
The Battle cards are incredible, and allowing up to all 4 (5 with expansion) players to participate in a single battle blows most other similar games (Kemet, as good as it is) away when they only allow 1v1 at a time.
The shrinking amount of space to fight only reinforces all of the drive towards aggression."

This is a game based on viking barbarians who long for a glorious death in battle so that they can enjoy the afterlife in the Valhalla. That being said, why such a game should have such simple and anticlimatic combat rules while being mostly an area control game with the chance of being swinged completely by an handful of gamechanging cards, is totally beyond me. The miniatures are nice, but they are not worth the "fights" they are going to be used for. With a completely different settings (and with more balanced cards), this game would work way better, but as it is, it's not about vikings having epic fights, it's about vikings having a stroll in the countryside and eventually sit down to play a completely broken card game. Pity.

THIS is my number one game of GenCon 2015. After one play under my belt, it was an instant hit.  After half a dozen plays, it is one of my favorite games.

I bought this on a whim on the first day because I knew it was going to sell out quickly.  I'd heard good reviews form several podcasters who all had wildly varying tastes so I knew there had to be something to the game that would appeal to me.   

Honestly, it is one of the best games I've ever played.  There is no fluff in this game.  Everything is essential.   One of the comments I've read said there is "chrome just for the sake of chrome" in this game.  I can't get on board with that statement. The minis are over the top gorgeous, of course, but everything else was so streamlined, from the uncluttered board to the functional, intuitive player mats.  It's not one of those huge FFG games with 1000 components.  There aren't dozens of different damage markers and status icons, etc...Everything has been stripped to the bare essentials in this game short of reducing the Minis to wooden cubes.  

There is so much to like here, but I'll focus on my favotirite thing:  Card drafting.  The card drafting is amazingly agonizing.  Not because you cann't find cards you want, but because every card is incredible.  You want them all.  And you know everyone else wants them all, and you definitely don't want to pass them anything juicy but you are going to!  The choice is between a fantastic card and several other fantastic cards.  Drafting is also easy for new players.  Each card is associated with a particular Norse God - just pick one or two names to focus on, draft them, and you'll have a great engine all ready to go!  But the great thing is that you don't really have to get locked into one particular strategy - you can change your strategy from round to round just by drafting a different set of cards.

This also plays surprisingly well with two, even though I miss seeing more variety in cards each round.  

Instantly one of my favorite games of all time.
Doesn't quite deliver due to random card draw from the draft and no real way to hate draft.  Minis are excellent.

I feel like I should like this game way more than I do. In theory, it should work for me. One of the issues may be the need for the group to self-correct. I've had a lot of runaway leader games of Blood Rage. Playing this with your head down like a Euro is a recipe for a bad time. Unless watching someone blow past everyone is your idea of a good time. And I've been on both ends of this: winning and losing. Neither of them were a fun experience. 

With enough plays, I'm sure it gets to a point where people see stopping someone from scoring is as good as scoring yourself, but I haven't seen that style of game yet. Adding in new people starts the process all over again. 

Would try this again, but there are so many other games I'd rather play that I probably wouldn't suggest it.

Blood Rage relation to Citow is kinda like ... 
[i]you know that dude you knew at high school that was really into metal, wore long hair and did crazy stuff all the time? Now you meet him 15 years later and you barely recognize him in his business suit, short hair, immaculate attire. But he claims deep down he's still rock'n'roll and shows you a tiny tattoo on his ankle (under Hugo Boss sock). [/i]

Instead of figuring out how BR is a hybrid (if it is) it would easier to point out where it's not an euro.  
- There's drafting, but not 7W style, but more of MtG vibe as what you draft becomes your hand. 
- err ... that's it, the rest is quite euroey. 

Sure, there's combat. Which manages to be even more deterministic and calculable than in Smallworld. You count the value of your armies and compare numbers, add some more numbers hidden in your hand and voila. But the numbers from your hand aren't really hidden as they were firstly drafted and secondly if you lost a combat everybody knows what you have. So, no tension here. And tension is even more diluted because people don't necessarily care about winning as there are ways to get more points by losing a fight. Huh? It's a good sign a game is far far away from ameritrash when visceral enjoyment that makes playing the game fun does not giveth points. This game is like the Risk version with the least amount of risk(ing) possible. 

What bothered me the most is how designer controlled everything is and how little impact players as a collective have on the dynamics of the game. You're just doing what you're doing, countering other people's plans (not people directly!). Cards are orchestrated into three balanced eras (blah). Where's groupthink? Where's bashing on the leader? (okay, there might be some traces of this, but didn't see it in our game). 

Oh yeah, remember the area majority thing Citow had? It's kinda sorta still there, but diluted - some cards you draft allow you to score majorities. But: Firstly - getting majority is not as hard to accomplish (as you have a choice between 2-3 different areas). Secondly - quests are hidden. So, while traces of area majority remain, it creates no tension thus its soul is gone. 

Blood Rage seems like a study in how to take the structure of Citow and make it as euro-ey (balanced, calculable, tension-less) as possible. While the game isn't as optimisation prone and MPS-ey as workerplacements, you can pick old school euros like T&E or El Grande and they have more player dynamics, more tension, more psychology, more people in them! 

Maybe this game is actually a different type of dude than I described above. 
[i]It's the metal dude guy you meet, but turns out, that's just his visual attire as he's managing 10 bands, organising 3 festivals, while having another million dollar business on the side, a yacht, and a villa in the posh part of town, and of course he's married into a rich political family. The metal thing -   merely make up.[/i]
(Yeah, those minis... just bling on top of an euro)

This is a very fun and interesting hybrid game. It combines drafting, action points, and combat mechanisms.

Over the course of the game every player will develop a unique clan that has it's own unique strengths and approach to earning glory. And each approach is a legitimate winning strategy, if executed well. Speaking of earning glory, the gameplay and the theme (of viking clans vieing to earn glory before ragnorok) are perfectly integrated.

Finally, it has to be said - this game is gorgeous, especially if you paint the figures. The Kickstarter extras are great, but I haven't felt deprived for not having them. Set up this game at a meetup and you will _always_ attract potential players.

Overall it's a really nice area control game. The drafting component unfortunately exacerbates the problems that are already bound to occur if you have players with different experience levels at the same table.

The main advantage of Blood Rage is probably the potentially lower play time. The difference isn't significant enough for me to choose this over other area control games. So I'll probably end up playing things like Rising Sun, Lords of Hellas or Cry Havoc instead of Blood Rage.

EDIT: I considered raising this a bit, but for now did not. The first time I played this half the players basically knew all the cards that were in the draft while the other half (including me) had seen maybe one or two cards during the rules explanation. Maybe that really was the problem.

Take note that, for my BGG ratings, I always stick to the BGG rating "descriptions", meaning: My rating reflects how much I personally want to play a certain game, where a 6 is a "will play if in the mood" and a 7 represents a "usually willing to play" and on that scale a 6.9 just is where Blood Rage belongs for me. I'm not trying to give objective review scores ... and I just felt like mentioning this now because in this special case my rating is especially low compared what I might rate this at if I were trying to hand out objective scores ... probably one of the largest discrepancies on my entire list.

EDIT: In my personal "want to play" rating competitive games like this one have fallen significantly and the rating just no longer did reflect my willingness to play these types of games, since there were quite a few games between 6.1 and 6.9 that I'd much rather play.

Held off purchasing it originally because I though it looked complicated...but boy was I wrong. It implements a very clean and streamlined drafting mechanic which dictates which actions you will likely implement during that round. This mechanic supports multiple strategy styles from round to round and there are many routes to victory, something not seen much in area control/fighting games. A  fighting game that can be taught and learned very quickly, offers multiple paths to victory AND plays pretty quickly...this is the only one that I know in my collection that ticks off all those boxes.

Better than Kemet. Doesn't fire CitOW as I heard from some people, this is more comparable to Kemet as it is focused more on unique upgrade paths rather than innate asymmetry. Instead of drafting from face up upgrades ala Kemet, you draft like a card game.

Feels like a tight design where the diff paths are very balanced yet you still get to feel powerful and do crazy shit so it doesn't feel too sterile.

You are rewarded for predicting your opponents intentions because of the action point system which is cool.

On the downside, all the different ways to get points are so balanced that they lead to lots of little optimizations at times (micromanaging VP i find not fun). I guess they call this "Victory Point Salad"

I feel like it won't have as much replay for me as I'd want it to, and actually expect rating would trend downward on repeated play, but for now I'll give it the benefit of the doubt as first play was really fun.

4 Player Game: 9/10. The four player game fixed all of the problems below. The drafting, while it took a longer time, made the game more balanced. The person who won actually beat all of us by  creating a Valhalla engine that was giving him 5 points for each figure that he released from Valhalla (ended up with a 55 point swing). I was going for the quest route and lost by about 10 points. The game is much longer with 4 players (especially if some are new to the game), but it makes the game much more tense, exciting and balanced. 



2-player game: 4/10. It's kind of hard to rate as I only played a two-player game which was a horrible idea. The mechanics and game play were decent, and obviously the miniatures are amazing, but the two player game was horrendous. First round, my wife won a huge battle by playing  a +5  from her hand, and that was it for me. After being decimated in that battle, I could not come back. She was able to freely pillage the board while I had to spend the rest of my turns getting people back on the board.  Since the warriors carry over, she maintained her dominance the rest of the game. Also I had the misfortune of drafting 0 quest cards during the final round--making it literally impossible to win; I just forfeited instead. So, while I can see that there is a good game at the core here, this is one of the worst two player games I have ever played; a game like Inis has a much better battle system for 2.

The game is not complicated. You draft cards each round, which you can use to customize your clan (they all start the same). These give you new abilities, recruit additional forces, etc. They are associated with one of several gods, each with a particular style of effect (e.g., better combat, more VP, tricky effects). After the draft, everyone takes actions one at a time -- move on the board, attack, etc. At the end of the round, VP is awarded for control of one of the regions (specified at the start of the round, subject to change based on some card effects).

There are some interesting systems at work, but you definitely have to be aware of the card powers and such -- I, at least, would need additional plays! This might be worth another go despite the drafting, although I doubt it will become a favorite of mine.

Only a few games in right now, so the rating is subject to change. The game is pretty to look at, has great concepts and found a way to avoid the issue of the "drôle de guerre", where no player wants to attack because of its weakening effect on one's forces. It's a stretched logic though: I understand the glory of dying in combat, but it becomes a rather poor justification for voluntarily killing tons of units through suicidal VP generation.

My biggest gripe with Blood Rage right now is how chaotic the games have turned out to be. Card effect ranges from "slight advantage" to "game changer" or even "VP maelstrom". When you trigger a conflict (pillage) you just have to hope some wild effect will not turn your well-thought plans into a shockingly bad move, but there is not that much you can do to anticipate. Costs seems off too. There is a "1-cost" card that allows you to get a VP for every unit lost at the end of an age, while other costlier cards have very situational effects and/or lower VP potential. Green cards are a bit curious too. It's usually pretty easy to fill the requirements, having not to win a territory, but only dominate in one of the region's territory. It's hard to tell that a player is even trying to fill a quest requirement by looking at its actions, and the fight for territorial dominance has rarely been tensed and harshly contested.

Sure, you can technically see several cards in play in a given age through the draft; sure, the draft tends to create a "somewhat" equal distribution of strong cards, but I have started to see this mechanism as a warning label: how wild can you go with cards imbalance by simply telling yourself, as a designer, that the draft will just even things out? And the logic has its limits too. In any case, all of this brings the game closer to Ameritrash than I expected when I was reading the rules.

Overall, this turns out more negative that I wanted it to be, and I have yet to play more, but I had high expectations.

Was extremely skeptical about this game and was turned off by the hype it had. Played this weekend and... amazing.

The theming and miniatures are spot on of course, but the gameplay is really where it shines. I really liked the drafting in Blood Rage. A lot of tension in choosing which cards to keep and which cards to pass to the other players.

I was also pleasantly surprised that Blood Rage played more like a euro, yet it still scratched that "fight and kill with my units on a board" itch. I liked that there were a lot of strategic decisions in how much you might commit to Yggdrasil or if you might sacrifice units for more glory or whether to focus more on battles or quests and how that affected the drafting phase.

Just altogether a great package. Simple but deep. Random enough with the drafting that it's pretty fair, even for those who have not played before. Love it.

This is a must play game and it deserves to earn a spot in your collection.

Btw for all of you who says that Loki strategy is OP: Learn how to play, and you will realise how easily you can counter that. Last three games I played I won against Loki strategy.

Played at two players, and the game was both interesting and entertaining, but the area control dynamic would have been more interesting with three or more players, as it means that each faction can choose whether to engage or not.  At two players, if a "Pillage" action is not contested, then the pillaging player automatically gains the rewards.  I also felt that it was inherently more valuable to gain the Rage rewards early, in order to be able to take more action in later rounds, whereas having higher axes was not as important given that the glory rewards for quests were guaranteed, but glory was not gained in uncontested pillage actions.
At a four player count, we found that the game had a runaway leader, based on a card combination that we could not have predicted, and that we could not interrupt. It was not a fun experience for both the winner and the losers.

Finally played this for the first time at my FLGS and I can see what makes it so popular! Even though didn't know the cards when the first draft started, by the final round I was able to make good choices and found myself in contention at the end of the game, winding up second. Smooth play, relatable mechanisms, and a fun time!

Inexplicably popular point-salad euro in Ameritash clothing. Miniatures are deployed to the regions of the game board, which can be "pillaged". If uncontested, the player takes the value of the bonus tile there; if contested, all present players play an attack bonus card, add up their units' strengths and the winner scores glory points from the battle. It's also possible to score glory from special cards, from dead units, from completed quests (typically have the most strength in a specific region at the end of the round), having units in a specific location destroyed at the end of the round and so on. Timing, tension, blah blah blah.

Despite the miniatures -- not Games Workshop calibre but otherwise excellent: better than previous CMoN games and substantially better than "boardgame quality" -- it's very much a euro in style. The key strategic element is the card drafting at the start of each round, and the issues typical of that mechanism are compounded by the limited card pool (many single cards) and strong focus on card synergy. A player's success is to some degree predicated on both random card distribution and on their opponents' willingness to hate-draft.

The rest of the play is highly tactical, with broader strategic concerns emerging chiefly in determining which units to leave on the board for the next round and where. But drafting again makes this difficult; planning for specific quests, for example, is unreliable. As expected from an Eric Lang game, chaotic special card powers abound, so there is certainly no such thing as a sure thing. 

This is another hybrid design that seems to me like the worst of both worlds. From its Ameritrash lineage it gets expensive miniatures and random effects; on the euro side it gets unthematic, abstract point-salad. The theme works only if you try very hard.

Don't get me wrong, the game does work. There are, being charitable, multiple paths to victory (uncharitable: several ingredient ratios to compose a salad), and genuine player differentiation emerges from the card draft. There is significant direct player interaction. It's just not enough.

What I find particularly bizarre are the favourable comparisons to Cthulhu Wars, a game with some similar mechanisms but genuine asymmetry, much more focused gameplay and much more theme. I would choose it in a heartbeat ahead of this one.

If you are looking for a card drafting game, go for 7 wonders and if you are looking for a war game, take a look at Kemet

The underlying game is quite okay (without being good or great), although nothing spectacular. Apart from the drafting (which is good) most game decisions come down to a combat card bluff (like in Cosmic Encounter).
But what really disturbs me (and detracts from the game!) are the gorish illustrations and the (totally unnecessary) miniatures. They are even worsening the gameplay because they don't even show the strength of the character they portray (like a regular game counter would do). If you are a 10 year old boy, you probably find these miniatures cool, but for me they are crap.

In my first game I spanked everyone else at the table.  I had a really good first age and managed to pillage the central area.  Then in the second age I got wolfman, which combined with some Tyr's cards basically let me "halifax hammer" my way to victory.

I had the ability to keep my cards after combat.  I had the Wolfman who meant that each fight was only with monsters (so I couldn't be beaten by sheer numbers) and my Tyr's battle cards combined with my Tyr's clan upgrade and the battle card that let me play it for 3 strength after everyone had played their battle cards meant that I had a guaranteed 11 strength in every fight and my opponents could only use monsters in battle, meaning that they had to come up with at least 7 damage to beat me (which didn't happen).

I was able to get an early lead and in this game I never lost the fight for the centre and by the end I was almost apologising I had so badly snowballed the game.

I also had Fenrir who I used on the final round to grab 20 points.  I had to work for it though and it felt great when it came off.

Honestly this game was spoiled by the Wolfman.

This is definitely one of the best dudes on a map style games. At the end of the day though, that's really all it is. The hype for this game, is a little extreme in my opinion. I'm not sure, that if you just took away the over the top miniatures (especially those monster minis), that people wouldn't be quite so gaga over it. I guess that is part of the overall experience though. And please understand me when I say this is a really good game, just not the holy grail of games, that some make it out to be. The component quality is thru the roof on this game. Some of the best plastic minis out there. It has hybrid mechanics, that stand out, to make this better than most other games in its category. Along the same vein as Cyclades and Kemet. These games completely replace most of the old plastic heavy Amerithrash games of the past. They are all kind of an evolution, for that side of gaming. The more I talk it up, the more I wonder, if it really is worth the hype. Haha. I still didn't like it enough to keep it for myself, or my gaming group, but I can see why others do enjoy it. I guess it's fair to say, that if you like Amerithrash, and don't mind sacrificing the old dice battles, for better card and stat based area control/ battles, then you will like this game. One of the few 8's I will give to a game I didn't keep.

There are no strategic objectives to combat in the normal sense.  More often than not you are actually trying to get your guys killed.  You're units parachute in to anywhere on the board and, because everything is so close, mobility isn't really that much of a factor which makes it feel like a worker placement game.  Plus, card drafting through a deck of unintriguing choices is probably the most important mechanic in the game.  I'm down on Blood Rage because I was expecting a more traditional combat-oriented game and that's definitely my bad but as it is (a worker placement, card drafting mess) I think I kind of hate it.
Yay, Vikings!
Great game. Card drafting offers strategic choices, low AP amongst players when taking actions, quick and straightforward combat system.

Feels like there are some balance issues that take experienced players to self-balance. Not something I'm really a fan of in design as self-balancing feels a bit weird. The game is still fun and has a lot of cool upgrades and stuff, but I'm also disappointed about how the Kickstarter edition had so many special things that changes the game that isn't in other editions. Also, combat feels a bit lackluster in some aspects where you know you'll lose and won't have a chance of some crazy wins. Would maybe be better if there were more battles and more conflict with bigger swings, but definitely not a killer for me. Still fun and something I think is neat and good for a true Ameritrashy time.
